Stars of Design Award (2009) |website = {{URL|http://www.huntslonem.com/|Huntslonem.com}} }} '''Hunt Slonem''' (born '''Hunt Slonim''', July 18, 1951) is an American painter, sculptor, and printmaker. He is best known for his [[Neo-expressionism|Neo-Expressionist]] paintings of tropical birds, often based on a personal aviary in which he has been keeping from 30 to over 100 live birds of various species. Slonem's works are included in many important museum collections all over the world; he is exhibiting regularly at both public and private venues, and he has received numerous honors and awards.[http://www.powerhousebooks.com/site/?p=8923 Pleasure Palaces: The Art and Homes of Hunt Slonem ''[[powerHouse Books]]'' Official web site]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Early life== Hunt Slonem was born in [[Kittery, Maine]], in an [[upper middle class]] family, the eldest of four children. His father was a Navy officer, and mother – a homemaker who spent much of her time doing volunteer work. As a result of his father's military career, Slonem's family moved around as frequently as every two to three years. He lived in Hawaii, Virginia, Connecticut, California and Washington State. Slonem's grandmother was a Tennessee native who married a Minnesota-born amateur artist and educator who became the Superintendent of Public Schools in [[Duluth, Minnesota]]. It was Slonem's grandfather who always encouraged young Hunt to paint. "I grew up around painting, and my parents dabbled in painting themselves. I was given paints as a child, and I wanted to be a painter from first grade onwards," Slonem told the online magazine ''Art Interview''. His younger brother, Jeffrey Slonim, is a prolific journalist, and contributing editor of the ''[[Interview (magazine)|Interview Magazine]]'', and his cousin is the best-selling author [[Tama Janowitz]].{{cite news|url=http://www.art-interview.com/Issue_014/interview_Slonem_Hunt.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130117074723/http://www.art-interview.com/Issue_014/interview_Slonem_Hunt.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-01-17|title=Hunt Slonem|date=Spring 2012|publisher=''Art Interview online Magazine''|accessdate=28 December 2012}} After completing school, which included living in [[Nicaragua]] as an exchange student when he was 16 years old, Slonem commenced undergraduate studies at [[Vanderbilt University]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. He then spent about six months of his sophomore year at the [[Universidad de las Américas Puebla|University of the Americas]] in [[San Andrés Cholula, Puebla]], Mexico, but later graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in [[Painting]] and [[Art History]] from [[Tulane University]] in [[New Orleans, Louisiana]]. He also took courses at the reputable [[Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture]] in Maine, where he was exposed to such influential artists from the New York area as [[Louise Nevelson]], [[Alex Katz]], [[Alice Neel]], [[Richard Estes]], [[Jack Levine]], and [[Al Held]]. During that period, Slonem altered the "i" to an "e" in his family name as a nod to [[numerology]]. He moved to New York in 1973 to further his art practice, and [[Manhattan]] had become his consistent base ever since.{{cite news |url=http://pmc-mag.com/2012/03/hunt-slonem/|title=HOUSES AS MUSES |work=[[Patrick McMullan|PMc Magazine]] |date=March 2012|first=Jeffrey |last=Slonim}} ==Career== {{quote|I would say my whole life could be summed up by the word 'exotica'.|Hunt Slonem{{cite news |url=http://www.interviewmagazine.com/art/hunt-slonem-acadian-dreams|title=Lincoln is Hunt Slonem's Marilyn |work=[[Interview (magazine)|Interview]] Magazine |date=December 2011|first=Clare|last=Stein}}}} Hunt Slonem's artistic career began in New York, in the late 1970s. When he first came to Manhattan, in 1973, he was hired by the Department of Social Services to teach painting to senior citizens. He was unhappy at his job and seriously considered moving to Amsterdam when, unexpectedly, in 1975, he got a call from artist [[Janet Fish]] who offered him her studio for the summer. That telephone call turned Slonem's life around. Shortly afterwards, In 1976, Hunt Slonem received a painting grant from the Elizabeth Greenshields Foundation in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], [[Canada]], and began painting in earnest. His first solo show was held at New York's Harold Reed Gallery in 1977, followed by a major exhibition at the prestigious [[Fischbach Gallery]]. As Slonem's career progressed, he was introduced to people like [[Andy Warhol]], [[Liza Minnelli]], [[Sylvia Miles]], and [[Truman Capote]]. Through Jeffrey Slonim, who would later serve as an usher at Andy Warhol's funeral, he also met and befriended the Belgian-born actress Monique van Vooren, the star of Warhol's film ''[[Flesh for Frankenstein]]''. He soon became a habitué of New York's trendiest hot spots and an active participant in the city's burgeoning art scene. Slonem's move to New York had a profound influence on his development as an artist. According to the ''[[New York Times]]'', he fell in love with "a very particular kind of New York life, one most people can only fantasize about. But people this determinedly unusual do exist here, and that is one of the city's surest charms. They feed off the city and the city feeds off them." Novelist [[Tama Janowitz]] put it succinctly, saying, "His pictures are the subtext of Manhattan, an imaginary, vivid and grotesquely evocative world that bubbles beneath the paved-over, gray city of New York which he physically inhabits -- a city where people have come from all over the world, bringing their images of other places and other lives with them."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/25/nyregion/about-new-york-this-artist-draws-inspiration-from-his-birds-all-72-of-them.html?scp=5&sq=%22hunt+slonem%22&st=nyt |title=About New York; This Artist Draws Inspiration From His Birds, All 72 of Them|work=The [[New York Times]] |date=25 December 1991 |first=Douglas|last=Martin}} Despite living in the heart of Manhattan, Slonem remained true to his boyhood fascination with exotica, which he had developed as a youth in Hawaii and during his time as a foreign exchange student in [[Managua]], [[Nicaragua]]. His paintings expressed a strong affinity for nature, especially the various species of exotic butterflies and tropical birds living on the island. He soon became well known for creating grisaille paintings of small birds in their cages. He often painted them wet-on-wet and grit off the surfaces to denote wire enclosures after the birds had been strategically placed. Art critic [[Roberta Smith]] wrote in the ''New York Times'' that Slonem's "witty [[Formalism (art)|Formalism]] strategy meshes the creatures into the picture plane and sometimes nearly obliterates them as images, but it also suspends and shrouds them in a dim, atmospheric light that is quite beautiful. If [[Joseph Cornell]] had concentrated on painting, the results might have looked like this."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/03/25/arts/review-art-condo-creates-a-future-with-layers-of-nostalgia.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm |title=Review/Art |work=The [[New York Times]] |date=25 March 1988 |first=Roberta |last=Smith}} Birds also fill the surface of his largest project yet – a 6-foot by 86 foot [[mural]] he painted for the iconic [[Bryant Park|Bryant Park Grill Restaurant]] in New York City, completed in 1995. According to ''[[The New Yorker]]'', "The most notable aspect of the [restaurant's] interior is an 86-foot long mural by the artist Hunt Slonem, which depicts hundreds of birds, similar to those found in the artist's studio, where he can be found painting away with a bird or two perched on his shoulders."{{cite news |url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/1995/06/19/1995_06_19_032_TNY_CARDS_000370644 |title=Miracle on 42nd Street |work=[[The New Yorker]] |date=19 June 1995 |first=Brendan |last=Gill}} Hunt Slonem's oil paintings pivot between the fantastic and the natural. These natural forms ultimately become the subjects for many of his artworks, appearing in large lavishly colored paintings and constructed sculptures. As an artist, he endeavors to explore the many expressive faculties of color. His paintings are layered with thick brushstrokes of vivid color, often cut into in a cross-hatched pattern that adds texture to the overall surface of the painting. Slonem often hides his subjects "behind a grid of incised lines, blurring their contours and emphasizing the paint's tactile quality."{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0DEFD7153EF930A25752C1A9639C8B63&scp=21&sq=%22hunt+slonem%22&st=nyt |title=Art Review; Landscapes: Fantastic, Elemental Or Formal |work=The [[New York Times]] |date=13 November 2005 |first=Helen A. |last=Harrison}} This surface patterning combines with the rich colors and recognizable subject matter to create paintings that are physically and aesthetically rich. Poet and critic [[John Ashbery]] observed, "From the narrow confines of his grids, half cage, half perch, Slonem summons dazzling explosions of the variable life around us that need only to be looked at in order to spring into being."[[John Ashbery|Ashbery, John]]. "Hunt's Place", ''Didegnodiverso'', Turin, Italy, 1995 Slonem's obsessive and repetitive rendering of his subjects reflects his desire to explore issues of spatial complexity, compression and density in what the acclaimed [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] curator [[Henry Geldzahler]] deemed "a consistent investigation of post-cubist abstraction."[[Henry Geldzahler|Geldzahler, Henry]]. "Hunt Slonem", ''Kunst Editions/Jano Group'', New York, 1993 The repetitive imagery also makes a reference to Andy Warhol. "I was influenced by Warhol's repetition of soup cans and Marilyn," says Slonem. "But I'm more interested in doing it in the sense of prayer, with repetition... It's really a form of worship." He is not interested in realism or, unlike Warhol, in advertising or media, and his paintings are neither narrative nor specific in detail. Rather, Slonem's work is deeply rooted in the act of painting. His jarring color choices, spontaneous mark making, and scratched hatch marks are the result of his ongoing fascination with the manipulation and implementation of paint. For Slonem, cross-hatching has "a feeling of a tapestry, it's like weaving. I'm making colors bleed into each other, I'm revealing the under-painting. I'm making these marks to allow the light to come through, basically. So you're seeing about five levels of paint, instead of one."{{cite news |url=http://www.studio360.org/2012/feb/24/hunt-slonems-artist-aviary/ |title=Hunt Slonem's Artist Aviary |work=Studio360.org |date=24 February 2012|first=Kurt |last=Andersen}} It is this kind of devotion to the process of painting that prompted Henry Geldzahler to observe in 1993 that "Slonem is a painter, a painter's painter with an enormous bag of technical tricks which become apparent to the viewer the longer he stands before the work." Another recurring theme of Slonem's pictorial work is portrait painting, and that of [[Abraham Lincoln]] in particular. He is interested in history and memorabilia, and for him, the "larger-than-life" Lincoln is a catchall. In Slonem's words, "On [[Marilyn Monroe|Marilyn [Monroe]]]'s desk, she had a picture of her mother and a picture of Lincoln. And she said, 'I really didn't know who my father was, so it might as well be Abraham Lincoln.'" According to the ''[[Interview|Interview Magazine]]'', "Slonem's portraits of Lincoln feel personal, and in surprising ways, he's close to the long-deceased." "I work with diviners and mystics, and one of them started channeling Lincoln in my house," says Slonem. "[Lincoln] guided me to paint certain things, like my doves: he wanted me to paint them as a symbol of freedom." In the early 1980s, Slonem began working on a new series of so-called "Rabbit paintings." The idea for this critically acclaimed series{{cite news |url=http://www.browardpalmbeach.com/2010-01-28/culture/check-out-hunt-slonem-s-rabbit-art-at-the-coral-springs-museum/|title=Check Out Hunt Slonem's Rabbit Art at the Coral Springs Museum |work=[[New Times Broward-Palm Beach]] |date=28 January 2010|first=Michael|last=Mills}} came to him after he had discovered that the year of his birth, 1951, was the [[Rabbit (zodiac)|year of the Rabbit]] in the [[Chinese zodiac|Chinese zodiac calendar]]. He often repeats imagery in this series, just like in his other series, because, he told the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'', the act is similar to spiritual meditation: "Mantras are holy because you repeat them." This theme continued to inspire Slonem over the years, and the series is as prominent in his work today as it was over thirty years ago. Apart from painting, Slonem is also making sculptures, like the sizable, "Tocos," an 18-foot acrylic and aluminum tower of toucans exhibited at the [[Polk Museum of Art]] in 2012. He has also restored several historic houses. "I consider it part of my art form," Slonem said in an interview with ''NewsChief.com''. His "art form" also includes [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic revival]] furniture - in his homes, studios, and exhibits. In 2009, [[Bergdorf Goodman]], a luxury department store in New York City, recreated Slonem's distinct art-filled living room for its windows display.{{cite news |url=http://www.heralddeparis.com/bergdorf-goodman-x-hunt-slonem/25365 |title=Bergdorf Goodman x Hunt Slonem |work=Herald de Paris |date=26 February 2009|first=Julia|last=Chesky}} In Slonem's view, "Art incorporated with furniture becomes a work of art itself."{{cite news |url=http://www.newschief.com/article/20120119/NEWSCHIEF/201195025?p=1&tc=pg&tc=ar |title=Hunt Slonem exhibit on display at Polk Museum of Art through March |work=NewsChief.com |date=16 January 2012|first=Donna|last=Kelly}} In 2008, German automaker [[Audi]] enlisted Hunt Slonem to create an exclusive design for its sleek new [[Audi A5|A5 coupe]], and he created a one-of-a-kind design based on one of his oil painting for the car's exterior. "It's an earlier work of mine with birds flying through the sky; the original work is in the collection of the [[Colby College Museum of Art|Colby Museum]] in Maine, where I was born," said Slonem of the piece, which is painted in blues, blacks, reds, and whites with cockatoos. The mobile artwork was unveiled in conjunction with the [[New York International Auto Show]] at the Audi Forum in Manhattan. The "Hunt Slonem Audi A5," as it was dubbed, then toured Audi dealerships throughout the United States, before returning to New York where it was auctioned off to benefit a cancer research charity.{{cite news |url=http://www.fashionweekdaily.com/the-fix/article/21145 |title=Hunt Slonem's Creative Car|date=14 February 2008 |publisher=''[[Daily Front Row]]''}} In 2010, [[Albert Maysles]], the [[Academy Award|Oscar]]-nominated documentary filmmaker ([[Salesman (1969 film)|Salesman]], [[Gimme Shelter (1970 film)|Gimme Shelter]], [[Grey Gardens]]), announced that he will be shooting a feature-length [[documentary]] on Hunt Slonem's life and his art. In 2014, he collaborated with fashion accessories company [[Echo Design Group]] for a limited edition scarf and handbag collection.{{cite news |url=http://www.msfabulous.com/2014/08/echo-design-hunt-slonem-collaboration.html |title=Echo Design & Hunt Slonem Collaboration|date=8 August 2014 |publisher=''[[Ms. Fabulous]]''}} ==Museum exhibitions and collections== Since 1977, Slonem had solo shows at many prestigious contemporary art galleries including the [[Fischbach Gallery]] in New York{{Cite web |url=http://www.fischbachgallery.com/nyc/art/richard-friedberg/ |title=Art Gallery New York | Fischbach History' [[Fischbach Gallery |access-date=2012-12-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120826172631/http://www.fischbachgallery.com/nyc/art/richard-friedberg/ |archive-date=2012-08-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }} and the [[Serge Sorokko|Serge Sorokko Gallery]] in San Francisco.[http://www.sorokko.com/artists/slonem/slonem.html Hunt Slonem. [[Serge Sorokko|Serge Sorokko Gallery]] Official web site] His work has been exhibited globally, including in Madras, Quito, Venice, Gustavia, San Juan, Guatemala City, Paris, Amsterdam, Madrid, Stockholm, Oslo, Cologne, Tokyo, and Hong Kong. His work has been shown in thirty-one different museums{{Cite web |url=http://roanoke.edu/academics/academic_departments/fine_arts/olin_hall_galleries/permanent_collection/hunt_slonem.htm |title=Hunt Slonem. [[Roanoke College |access-date=2012-12-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606235341/http://roanoke.edu/Academics/Academic_Departments/Fine_Arts/Olin_Hall_Galleries/Permanent_Collection/Hunt_Slonem.htm |archive-date=2014-06-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }} including the [[Hunter Museum of American Art]] in [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]], in 1981; the [[:it:Museo diocesano d'arte sacra Sant'Apollonia|Museo Diocesano d'arte sacra Sant'Apollonia]] in Venice, Italy, in 1986; the [[Albany Museum of Art]] in [[Albany, Georgia]], in 2007; the [[Istanbul Museum of Modern Art]] in [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]], in 2007; [[:es:Museo de Arte de El Salvador|Museo de Arte de El Salvador]] in [[San Salvador]], [[El Salvador]], in 2010; the [[National Gallery for Foreign Art]] in [[Sofia]], [[Bulgaria]], in 2010; the [[Alexandria Museum of Art]] in [[Alexandria, Louisiana]] in 2011, and the [[Polk Museum of Art]] in [[Lakeland, Florida]] in 2012, to name just a few.{{cite news |url=http://www.novinite.com/view_news.php?id=115773 |title=US Foundation Brings Famous Artist Hunt Slonem to Bulgaria|date=30 April 2010 |publisher=''[[Novinite.com (Sofia News Agency)|Sofia News Agency]]''}}{{Cite web |url=http://polkmuseumofart.org/exhibitions/hunt-slonem-an-expressive-nature/ |title=Hunt Slonem: An Expressive Nature [[Polk Museum of Art |access-date=2012-12-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120510154111/http://polkmuseumofart.org/exhibitions/hunt-slonem-an-expressive-nature/ |archive-date=2012-05-10 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Slonem has been an active participant in the [[Art in Embassies Program]] sponsored by the [[United States Department of State]], alongside other American artists including [[Jim Dine]], [[Julian Schnabel]], [[Sol LeWitt]], [[Jasper Johns]], [[Ellsworth Kelly]], and [[Jeff Koons]], who received the first ever Medal of Arts from the Department of State for his "outstanding commitment" to the program.[http://www.mica.edu/news/secretary_of_state_clinton_awards_alumnus_jeff_koons_76_one_of_first_medals_of_arts.html Secretary of State Clinton awards alumnus Jeff Koons '76 One of the First Medals of Arts ''[[Maryland Institute College of Art]]'' Official web site] Through Art in Embassies, Slonem's paintings have been exhibited globally revealing, as [[Hillary Clinton]] put it, "the rich history and cultural heritage of the United States and the experiences that we share with peoples of different countries, backgrounds and faiths. Every exhibition reminds us of the diversity of mankind and the values that bind us together."{{Cite web |url=http://art.state.gov/about.aspx |title=Message from Secretary of State [[Federal government of the United States |access-date=2012-12-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130203042113/http://art.state.gov/about.aspx |archive-date=2013-02-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }}[http://art.state.gov/artistdetail.aspx?id=102152 Hunt Slonem. [[Federal government of the United States]] Official web site][http://art.state.gov/artistdetail.aspx?id=103420 Jim Dine. [[Federal government of the United States]] Official web site][http://art.state.gov/ArtistDetail.aspx?id=159380 Julian Schnabel. [[Federal government of the United States]] Official web site] Hunt Slonem's paintings are widely represented in important private collections all over the world. According to the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', "Slonem's work has attracted many well-known [Hollywood] art collectors including [[Sharon Stone]], [[Gina Gershon]], [[Brooke Shields]], [[Julianne Moore]], [[Mandy Moore]], [[Kate Hudson]], and [[J.Lo]]", among others.{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/default/photo/Painter-Hunt-Slonem-poses-for-a-portrait-with-his-2337471.php|title=Hunt Slonem Gallery a bright addition to SoMa |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |date=1 March 2010}} "I'm a big fan of Hunt's work," Brooke Shields told ''[[Daily Front Row]]''. "It's whimsical without being too sweet."{{cite news |url=http://www.fashionweekdaily.com/the-fix/article/21145 |title=Coach's Pleasure Palace|date=25 October 2007 |publisher=''[[Daily Front Row]]'' |accessdate=26 December 2012| first=Jennifer| last=Barton}} A March 2012 issue of ''[[Architectural Digest]]'' features Shields's Manhattan townhouse, with three of Slonem's "rabbit paintings" prominently displayed on her living room wall.{{cite news |url=http://www.architecturaldigest.com/celebrity-homes/2012/brooke-shields-new-york-city-townhouse-slideshow_slideshow_item2_3#slide=3 |title=An Exclusive look at Brooke Shields's Manhattan Home |work=Architectural Digest |date=March 2012|first=Judith|last=Thurman}} Over fifty museums internationally include Hunt Slonem's paintings in their collections,{{Dead link|date=September 2018}} among them the [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]];[http://americanart.si.edu/collections/search/artwork/results/index.cfm?rows=10&q=&page=1&start=0&fq=name:%22Slonem%2C%20Hunt%22 Hunt Slonem. ''Habitat'' [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]] Official web site] {{Dead link|date=September 2018}} the [[National Gallery of Art]] in Washington, D.C.;{{cite news |url=http://www.knowla.org/entry.php?rec=1358 |title=Hunt Slonem|work=Encyclopedia of Louisiana|date=29 May 2012 |first=J.Richard|last=Gruber}} the [[Brooklyn Museum of Art]] in Brooklyn, NY;[http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/artists/9518/Hunt_Slonem Hunt Slonem. ''Monsoon'' [[Brooklyn Museum of Art]] Official web site] the [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|Boston Museum of Fine Arts]] in Boston, Massachusetts;{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/default/article/Lories-Bunnies-and-Butterflies-Check-Into-The-3720320.php|title=Lories, Bunnies and Butterflies Check Into The Lenox Hotel In Boston, MA|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date=19 July 2012|access-date=2012-12-26|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130202103117/http://www.sfgate.com/default/article/Lories-Bunnies-and-Butterflies-Check-Into-The-3720320.php|archive-date=2013-02-02|dead-url=yes|df=}} [[Fundació Joan Miró]] in Barcelona, Spain; the [[Künzelsau|Würth Museum]] in Künzelsau, Germany; the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]],[http://www.metmuseum.org/Collections/search-the-collections/210003771 Hunt Slonem. ''St. Martin de Porres'' [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] Official web site] the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]],{{Cite web |url=http://whitney.org/Collection/AllArtists?artists_page=27 |title=Hunt Slonem. ''Untitled'' [[Whitney Museum of American Art |access-date=2012-12-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304050417/http://whitney.org/Collection/AllArtists?artists_page=27 |archive-date=2016-03-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }} and the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] all in New York.{{Dead link|date=September 2018}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.ou.edu/content/fjjma/experience/collections/contemporaryArt/slonem.html |title=Hunt Slonem. ''Green Cissa'' [[Fred Jones Jr. Museum of Art |access-date=2012-12-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121124190758/http://www.ou.edu/content/fjjma/experience/collections/contemporaryArt/slonem.html |archive-date=2012-11-24 |dead-url=yes |df= }}{{Cite web |url=http://www.centenary.edu/news/2010/0000086 |title=Museum presents Hunt Slonem, Works from Albania Plantation [[Centenary College of Louisiana |access-date=2012-12-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906070115/http://www.centenary.edu/news/2010/0000086 |archive-date=2015-09-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==Personal life== Hunt Slonem has never been married and has no children. Until 2010, he occupied a Tenth Street studio in Manhattan that was 40,000 square feet, divided into 89 rooms.{{cite news |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-1S9SxfyPmE |title=Hunt Slonem |work=Men.Style.com |date=7 December 2007}} In 2010, Slonem moved to a 15,000 square foot fourth floor former headquarters of the film company Moviola, on West 45th Street. The space served as his painting studio and was divided into a number of small rooms, all of which Slonem painted in old Louisiana plantation-house colors.{{cite news |url=http://www.interviewmagazine.com/culture/hunt-slonems-studio/|title=Hunt Slonem's Studio |work=[[Interview (magazine)|Interview]] Magazine|date=24 February 2012|first=Hunt |last=Slonem}} The studio housed his ever-expanding quirky collections, from [[Neo-Gothic]] chairs to top hats, to marble busts of [[Marie Antoinette]], to various [[Objet d'art|''objets d'art'']], mined from flea markets and antique fairs. In an interview in Vincent Katz's book ''Pleasure Palaces: The Art & Homes of Hunt Slonem,'' he describes his collecting technique as "cluttering."Katz, Vincent. ''Pleasure Palaces: The Art & Homes of Hunt Slonem,'' ''[[powerHouse Books]]'', New York, 2007 For him, objects are "friends;" the more there are, the more he is inspired. "I have to have a certain amount of stuff in place before I can function and paint," he says.{{cite news |url=http://nymag.com/homedesign/greatrooms/64276/|title=Living With a Thousand Best Friends|work= [[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]] |date=28 February 2010 |first=Wendy|last=Goodman}} Although, Slonem still lives in the loft apartment he moved into in 1973, according to the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'', he does nearly all his entertaining at his new 25,000 square foot West 34th Street studio in the industrial [[Hell's Kitchen, Manhattan|Hell's Kitchen]] neighborhood of Manhattan where he moved in 2011. He christened the third floor loft space with a birthday party attended by more than 200 people.{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204190504577040280261991196|title=An Oddball Menagerie|work= [[Wall Street Journal]]|date=19 November 2011 |first=Kelly|last=Crow}} Hunt Slonem also owns two historically important Louisiana plantations—one called [[Albania Plantation House|Albania Plantation]], on the [[Bayou Teche]] in [[St. Mary Parish, Louisiana|St. Mary Parish]], about two hours' drive northwest of [[New Orleans]], and the other – the Lakeside Plantation, in a remote location near the town of Batchelor, one hour north of [[Baton Rouge]]. According to the ''New York Times'', the Batchelor property includes "an 1832 plantation house called Lakeside, pink if you please, as surprising in this community of shoebox houses as an aged diva in a pink organdy dress at McDonald's. Also as indifferent, inasmuch as a house can be indifferent, to the bruising of time."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/31/garden/31hunt.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1& |title=Southern Gothic: Ghosts Welcome|work=The [[New York Times]] |date=31 May 2007 |first=Joyce|last=Wadler}} It was once owned by [[Marquis de La Fayette]] whose close relationship with lifelong friends such as [[Thomas Jefferson]], [[Benjamin Franklin]], [[James Monroe]], [[John Adams]], and [[Robert R. Livingston (chancellor)|Robert Livingston]] played a pivotal role in the [[Louisiana Purchase]]. In a show of gratitude, the United States gave La Fayette land which is known today as Lakeside Plantation.[http://www.acadianmuseum.com/marquis.html Acadian Museum Exhibit: 2007 Marquis de La Fayette Commemoration: “The Overlooked Legacy of La Fayette: The Louisiana Purchase” [[Erath, Louisiana|Acadian Museum]] Official web site] The property is listed in the [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Louisiana]]. ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=38em}} == Bibliography == * ''The Worlds of Hunt Slonem'' by Dominique Nahas; Vendome Press, New York, 2011 * ''Hunt Slonem: The feather game'' by Hunt Slonem; Marlborough Chelsea, New York, 2008 * ''Pleasure Palaces: The Art & Homes of Hunt Slonem'' by Vincent Katz; powerHouse Books, New York, 2007 * ''Hunt Slonem: An Art Rich and Strange'' by Donald B. Kuspit; Harry N. Abrams Books Incorporated, New York, 2007 * ''Hunt Slonem: Saints & Angels'' by J. William Zeitlin, Hunt Slonem, et al.; [[Ursuline College]], 2007 * ''Exotica'' by Vincent Katz et al.; Edizioni d'Arte Fratelli Pozzo, Turin, Italy, 1997 * ''Hunt's Place'' by Vincent Katz, Ronny Cohen, and John Ashbery; Didegnodiverso, Turin, Italy, 1995 * ''Hunt Slonem'' by [[Henry Geldzahler]] (Foreword); Kunst Editions/Jano Group, New York, 1993 * ''Hunt Slonem: Paradise Elsewhere'' by Holland Cotter and David J. Messer Slonem, [[Bergen Museum of Art and Science]], Hackensack, NJ, 1990 * ''Hunt Slonem'' by Holland Cotter and David J. Messer Slonem, [[Bergen Museum of Art and Science]], Hackensack, NJ, 1990 ==External links== * {{YouTube|zmLNCZWhCmk|Hunt Slonem}} ''[[CBS Sunday Morning]]'' * {{YouTube|qn_QrCs_pzM|Kurt Andersen interviews artist Hunt Slonem}} ''Studio 360'' * {{YouTube|M5UvLjPCTJ4|A visit with Hunt Slonem at his Albania Plantation home}} ''[[Louisiana Public Broadcasting]]'' * [http://issuu.com/avenueinsider/docs/050112/54 Hunt Slonem's Wonderland] ''Avenue Magazine'' * [http://museum.louisiana.edu/Files/Articles/slonemcatalogue.pdf Hunt on the Bayou]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''[[Paul and Lulu Hilliard University Art Museum]]'' * [http://www.dtrmodern.com/artists.php?id=132 DTR Modern Galleries, Boston/New York/Palm Beach/Washington, DC] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Slonem, Hunt}} [[Category:20th-century American painters]] [[Category:American male painters]] [[Category:21st-century American painters]] [[Category:American collectors]] [[Category:Sculptors from New York (state)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Postmodern artists]] [[Category:Animal artists]] [[Category:Public art]] [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:Artists from Louisiana]] [[Category:Tulane University alumni]] [[Category:People from Kittery, Maine]] [[Category:Artists from Maine]] [[Category:20th-century American sculptors]] [[Category:American male sculptors]] [[Category:20th-century American printmakers]]

([[Arlington, Texas]]) | college = [[Baylor Bears basketball|Baylor]] (2012–2014) | draft_year = | career_start = 2017 | years1 = 2017 | team1 = [[KK FMP Beograd|FMP]] | years2 = 2017 | team2 = Guangxi Rhino | years3 = 2017 | team3 = [[Yulon Luxgen Dinos]] | years4 = 2018 | team4 = [[Champville SC]] | years5 = 2018 | team5 = Guangxi Rhino | years6 = 2018–present | team6 = [[Nanjing Monkey King]] | highlights = *[[Big 12 Conference|Big 12]] All-Defensive Team ([[2013–14 Big 12 Conference men's basketball season|2014]]) *[[National Invitation Tournament|NIT]] champion ([[2013 National Invitation Tournament|2013]]) *Third-team All-Big 12 ([[2012–13 Big 12 Conference men's basketball season|2013]]) *Big 12 All-Rookie Team (2013) *[[McDonald's All-American Game|McDonald's All-American]] ([[2012 McDonald's All-American Boys Game|2012]]) }} '''Isaiah Charles Austin''' (born October 25, 1993) is an American professional [[basketball]] player for [[Nanjing Monkey King]] of the [[Chinese Basketball Association]] (CBA). He played two years of college basketball for [[Baylor Bears basketball|Baylor University]]. He had been considered a first-round prospect in the [[2014 NBA draft]] until he was diagnosed with [[Marfan syndrome]].[http://blog.chron.com/ultimaterockets/2014/06/nba-makes-austins-dreams-come-true-with-gesture-at-draft/ NBA makes Austin’s dreams come true with gesture at draft] In 2016, he was cleared to continue playing basketball after a two-year stint away from the game due to Marfan syndrome. ==High school career== Austin attended [[Grace Preparatory Academy]] in [[Arlington, Texas]]. As a senior in 2011–12, he averaged 15 points, 11 rebounds and five blocks per game, earning back-to-back ''Fort Worth Star-Telegram Super Team'' Player of the Year honors. Austin participated in the 2012 McDonald's All-American Game, 2012 Adidas Nations and the 2012 Jordan Brand Classic. He was named to the ESPNHS All-American Elite second team and was the nation's no. 3 recruit according to ESPN.{{cite web|url=http://www.baylorbears.com/sports/m-baskbl/mtt/isaiah_austin_810664.html|title=Isaiah Austin Bio|work=BaylorBears.com|accessdate=June 28, 2013}} ==College career== As a freshman at [[Baylor Bears basketball|Baylor]] in 2012–13, Austin earned third-team All-Big 12 and Big 12 All-Rookie Team honors. On April 4, 2013, he recorded 15 points, nine rebounds, five blocks, four assists and two steals in the NIT championship game in which Baylor defeated Iowa 74–54.[http://scores.espn.com/ncb/recap?gameId=330940239 Pierre Jackson lifts Baylor past Iowa, to first NIT crown] In 35 games (all starts), he averaged 13.0 points, 8.3 rebounds, 1.1 assists and 1.7 blocks in 29.9 minutes per game.[https://www.sports-reference.com/cbb/players/isaiah-austin-1.html Isaiah Austin Stats] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140622222518/http://www.sports-reference.com/cbb/players/isaiah-austin-1.html |date=2014-06-22 }} In April 2013, Austin declared for the [[2013 NBA draft]], but later returned to Baylor due to a shoulder injury.{{cite web|last=King|first=Jason|url=http://www.espn.com/blog/collegebasketballnation/post/_/id/84016/injury-sways-baylors-austin-to-return|title=Injury sways Baylor's Austin to return|work=ESPN.com|date=April 30, 2013|accessdate=June 28, 2013}} As a sophomore in 2013–14, Austin earned Big 12 All-Defensive Team honors. In 38 games, he averaged 11.2 points, 5.5 rebounds, 1.4 assists and 3.1 blocks in 28.0 minutes per game. On April 22, 2014, Austin declared for the [[2014 NBA draft]], forgoing his final two years of college eligibility.[http://www.cbssports.com/collegebasketball/eye-on-college-basketball/24536190/baylors-isaiah-austin-declares-for-nba-draft Baylor's Isaiah Austin declares for NBA draft] ==Professional career== ===Marfan syndrome diagnosis=== On June 22, 2014, Austin learned that he had been diagnosed with [[Marfan syndrome]], a genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue. In an emotional interview with [[ESPN]]'s [[Holly Rowe]], Austin said that he could no longer play basketball at a competitive level since the arteries in his heart were abnormally large, and there was too much risk of his aorta rupturing if he continued to play. In response, NBA commissioner [[Adam Silver]] invited Austin to attend the draft as his guest.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/draft2014/story/_/id/11119553/former-baylor-star-isaiah-austin-career-ending-medical-condition |title=Isaiah Austin has Marfan syndrome |work=ESPN.com |date=June 22, 2014 |accessdate=June 22, 2014}} Shortly after Austin's diagnosis was made public, his agent revealed that Austin had taken out an insurance policy against career-ending disability through a special NCAA program, which was worth at least [[United States dollar|$]]1 million. The policy would not have paid out if Austin's career ended due to his eyesight or his shoulder, but was expected to pay out due to his Marfan diagnosis.{{cite web |last=Rovell |first=Darren |url=http://www.espn.com/nba/draft2014/story/_/id/11125572/former-baylor-bears-star-isaiah-austin-1-million-insurance-policy |title=Isaiah Austin has $1M 'elite' policy |work=ESPN.com |date=June 23, 2014 |accessdate=June 24, 2014}} On June 26, 2014, between the 15th and 16th picks of the [[2014 NBA draft]], NBA Commissioner [[Adam Silver]] made Austin a ceremonial pick, which fulfilled his dream of getting drafted. The crowd gave him a standing ovation as he walked up to the podium. He was offered a job in the NBA by Adam Silver, with the stipulation that he finishes his degree at Baylor University.{{cite web|last=Fitzgerald|first=Matt|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2138070-isaiah-austin-offered-job-with-nba-after-health-condition-ended-career|title=Isaiah Austin Offered Job with NBA After Health Condition Ended Career|work=BleacherReport.com|date=July 22, 2014|accessdate=July 23, 2014}} ===Return to basketball=== On November 30, 2016, Austin was medically cleared to play basketball and began considering offers from overseas.{{cite web|url=http://www.zagsblog.com/2016/11/30/former-baylor-big-man-isaiah-austin-cleared-play-basketball/|title=Former Baylor Big Man Isaiah Austin Cleared to Play Basketball Again|work=zagsblog.com|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://cassyathena.com/2016/11/30/exclusive-interview-with-isaiah-austin-finally-cleared-to-play-basketball/|title=Exclusive interview with Isaiah Austin – finally cleared to play basketball!|work=cassyathena.com|date=November 30, 2016|accessdate=November 30, 2016}} On January 7, 2017, he signed his first professional contract with Serbian club [[KK FMP Beograd|FMP]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/18428594/isaiah-austin-signs-professional-contract-fmp-belgrade|title=Isaiah Austin signs pro contract with Serbia's FMP Belgrade|work=ESPN.com|date=January 7, 2017|accessdate=January 8, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sportando.com/en/cups/aba-liga/222467/isaiah-austin-signs-first-pro-contract-with-kk-crvena-zvezda-affiliate-team-fmp.html|title=Isaiah Austin signs first pro contract with KK Crvena Zvezda affiliate team FMP|work=Sportando.com|date=January 8, 2017|accessdate=January 8, 2017}} He made his debut for FMP on January 15, 2017, recording nine points and four rebounds in a 92–85 win over [[KK Mornar Bar|Mornar Bar]].{{cite web|url=http://www.aba-liga.com/match.php?id=124&tab=statistic_Stats|title=FMP vs Mornar – Full Statistics|work=aba-liga.com|date=January 15, 2017|accessdate=January 16, 2017}} In 12 [[Basketball League of Serbia|KLS]] games, he averaged 7.6 points and 3.9 rebounds per game. He also averaged 9.1 points, 3.2 rebounds and 1.2 blocks in nine [[Adriatic League]] games. In July 2017, Austin joined Guangzhi Weizhuang of the Chinese [[National Basketball League (China)|NBL]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sportando.com/en/world/asia/240586/isaiah-austin-will-play-in-china-with-guangxi-rhinos.html|title=Isaiah Austin will play in China with Guangxi Rhinos|work=Sportando.com|date=July 9, 2017|accessdate=July 16, 2017}} In 16 games for Guangxi, he averaged 34.6 points, 13.4 rebounds, 2.8 assists, 1.1 steals and 4.3 blocks per game. On November 11, 2017, Austin signed with the [[Yulon Luxgen Dinos]] of the [[Super Basketball League]].{{cite web|url=https://www.sportando.com/en/asia/taiwan/253467/isaiah-austin-inks-with-yulon.html|title=Isaiah Austin inks with Yulon|work=Sportando.com|date=November 11, 2017|accessdate=November 11, 2017}} He appeared in three games for Yulon before leaving the team in mid-December. On January 20, 2018, Austin signed with [[Champville SC|Champville]] of the [[Lebanese Basketball League]].{{cite web|url=https://www.sportando.com/en/asia/lebanon/261947/isaiah-austin-signs-with-champville.html|title=Isaiah Austin signs with Champville|work=Sportando.com|date=January 20, 2018|accessdate=January 20, 2018}} He appeared in four games for Champville before leaving the team in February. In June 2018, Austin re-joined Guangxi Rhino of the Chinese NBL.{{cite web|url=https://sportando.basketball/en/asia/china/268824/isaiah-austin-agreed-to-return-to-guangxi-for-chinese-nbl-season.html|title=Isaiah Austin agreed to return to Guangxi for Chinese NBL season|work=sportando.basketball|date=March 22, 2018|accessdate=August 25, 2018}} On October 16, 2018, Austin signed with [[Nanjing Monkey King]] of the [[Chinese Basketball Association]].{{cite web |last1=Lupo |first1=Nicola |title=Isaiah Austin signs with Nanjing Tongxi Monkey King |url=https://sportando.basketball/en/isaiah-austin-signs-with-nanjing-tongxi-monkey-king/ |publisher=Sportando |accessdate=October 16, 2018 |date=October 16, 2018}} ==Philippine national team== In September 2017, the [[Samahang Basketbol ng Pilipinas]] began the process of including Austin in their [[Philippines men's national basketball team|men's national basketball team]], to be considered as a naturalized player in the future.{{cite web|last=Li|first=Matthew|url=http://tiebreakertimes.com/tbt/chooks-to-go-pilipinas-taps-isaiah-austin-as-import-eyed-as-naturalized-player-candidate/95213|title=Chooks-to-Go Pilipinas taps Isaiah Austin as import, eyed as naturalized player candidate|work=TieBreakerTimes.com|date=September 10, 2017|accessdate=September 12, 2017}}{{cite web|last=Leongson|first=Randolph B.|url=http://sports.inquirer.net/264404/chooks-to-go-gilas-to-tap-isaiah-austin-fiba-asia-champions-cup|title=Gilas taps Austin, Akhuetie for Fiba Asia Champions Cup|work=Inquirer.net|date=September 10, 2017|accessdate=September 12, 2017}}{{cite web|last=Taningco|first=Brad|url=https://clutchpoints.com/isaiah-austin-considered-naturalized-philippines-team/|title=Isaiah Austin being considered to be naturalized to play for Philippines’ national team|work=ClutchPoints.com|date=September 11, 2017|accessdate=September 12, 2017}} He suited up as an import for [[Chooks-to-Go Pilipinas]], the national team competing as a club, at the [[2017 FIBA Asia Champions Cup]]. They finished the tournament in fifth place, with Austin recording 37 points, 15 rebounds, six assists and six blocks in their final game of the tournament.{{cite web|last=Lintag|first=Paul|url=http://sports.abs-cbn.com/basketball/news/2017/09/30/austin-s-monster-game-hands-5th-place-chooks-pilipinas-31613|title=Austin's monster game hands 5th place to Chooks-Pilipinas|work=abs-cbn.com|date=September 30, 2017|accessdate=October 2, 2017}} ==Career statistics== ===Adriatic League=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:95%; text-align:center;" ! Season ! Team ! League ! {{Tooltip|GP|Games Played}} ! {{Tooltip|MPG|Minutes Per Game}} ! {{Tooltip|FG%|Field Goal Percentage}} ! {{Tooltip|3P%|3 Point Field Goal Percentage}} ! {{Tooltip|FT%|Free Throw Percentage}} ! {{Tooltip|RPG|Rebounds Per Game}} ! {{Tooltip|APG|Assists Per Game}} ! {{Tooltip|SPG|Steals Per Game}} ! {{Tooltip|BPG|Blocks Per Game}} ! {{Tooltip|PPG|Points Per Game}} |- | [[2016–17 ABA League|2016–17]] || [[KK FMP Beograd|FMP]] || [[ABA League|Adriatic League]] || 9 || 15.6 || .525 || .429 || .600 || 3.2 || 0.4 || 0.1 || 1.2 || 9.1 |} ===FIBA Asia Champions Cup=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:95%; text-align:center;" ! League ! {{Tooltip|GP|Games Played}} ! {{Tooltip|MPG|Minutes Per Game}} ! {{Tooltip|FG%|Field Goal Percentage}} ! {{Tooltip|3P%|3 Point Field Goal Percentage}} ! {{Tooltip|FT%|Free Throw Percentage}} ! {{Tooltip|RPG|Rebounds Per Game}} ! {{Tooltip|APG|Assists Per Game}} ! {{Tooltip|SPG|Steals Per Game}} ! {{Tooltip|BPG|Blocks Per Game}} ! {{Tooltip|PPG|Points Per Game}} |- | [[2017 FIBA Asia Champions Cup|2017]] || [[Philippines men's national basketball team in FIBA club tournaments|Chooks-To-Go Pilipinas]] || [[FIBA Asia Champions Cup]] || 7 || 32.6 || .553 || .167 || .732 || 13.0 || 2.4 || 0.4 || 3.1 || 20.0 |} ==Personal life== Austin is blind in his right eye from a spontaneous retinal detachment that occurred during middle school. He had kept the visual loss a secret, known only to his teammates and close friends until January 17, 2014.{{cite web|last=Zucker|first=Joseph|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1928523-isaiah-austins-comeback-makes-him-one-of-most-compelling-players-in-country|title=Isaiah Austin's Comeback Makes Him One of agent.[https://www.sbnation.com/lookit/2014/12/16/7405489/you-can-now-play-as-isaiah-austin-in-nba-2k15 You can now play as Isaiah Austin in NBA 2K15] Austin is the nephew of nine-year NBA veteran [[Isaac Austin]].[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-06-23/baylor-7-footer-has-nba-dream-ended-by-rare-genetic-condition Baylor 7-Footer Has NBA Dream Ended by Rare Genetic Condition] {{Infobox person |name = Jeffrey Goldberg |image = Jeffrey Goldberg and President Obama.jpg |caption = Goldberg with President Obama at the Oval Office, 2014 |birth_name = Jeffrey Mark Goldberg |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1965|9|22}} |birth_place = [[Brooklyn, New York]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |citizenship = United States
Israel |occupation = Journalist, writer, editor-in-chief of [[The Atlantic]]{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/news/archive/2016/10/jeffrey-goldberg-atlantic-editor-in-chief/503573/|title=The Atlantic's New Editor in Chief|first=Krishnadev|last=Calamur|publisher=[[The Atlantic]]}} | party = [[Democratic Party (US)|Democratic Party]]{{cite web|title=List of Registered Voters|url=https://www.dcboee.org/pdf_files/ListOfRegisteredVoters051616.pdf|publisher=District of Columbia Board of Elections|accessdate=13 February 2017|page=3871|date=30 May 2016}} |spouse = {{marriage|Pamela Ress Reeves|1993}} |children = 3 |awards = [[National Magazine Award]], [[Overseas Press Club]]'s Joe & Laurie Dine Award |website = [http://www.jeffreygoldberg.net Jeffrey Goldberg's personal website] |credits = ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The New York Times Magazine]]'', ''[[The Atlantic Monthly|The Atlantic]]'', ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'', ''[[The New Yorker]]'', ''[[New York Book Review]]'', ''[[The Forward]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'', ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'', ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]''{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} |alma mater = [[University of Pennsylvania]] }} '''Jeffrey Mark Goldberg''' (born September 22, 1965) is an American journalist and the editor-in-chief of ''[[The Atlantic Monthly|The Atlantic]]''. During his nine years at ''The Atlantic'' prior to becoming editor, Goldberg became known for his coverage of foreign affairs. He has won many awards and written eleven cover stories for the magazine. ==Early life and education== Goldberg was born to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family{{Cite web|last= Marcy |first= Oster |authorlink= |title= Politico Editor Hadas Gold Gets Vicious Threats from Donald Trump Backer |publisher=[[Jewish Daily Forward]]|date=October 19, 2016 |url=https://forward.com/news/breaking-news/352247/politico-editor-hadas-gold-gets-vicious-threats-from-donald-trump-backer/ |accessdate=}} in [[Brooklyn, New York]], the son of Ellen and Daniel Goldberg,{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/06/28/style/pamela-reeves-jeffrey-goldberg.html?src=pm|title=Pamela Reeves, Jeffrey Goldberg|date=June 28, 1993|work=The New York Times}} whom he describes as "very left-wing."{{cite news|url=http://www.tabletmag.com/podcasts/3179/across-the-great-divide|title=Across the Great Divide|date=October 16, 2006|publisher=Tablet Magazine|last1=Ivry|first1=Sara|accessdate=October 11, 2016}} He grew up in suburban [[Malverne, New York|Malverne]] on [[Long Island]], where he recalled being one of the few Jews in a largely Irish-American area. During his first trip to Israel as "a powerless 13-year-old boy suffering at the hands of Irish pogromists, juvenile pogromists," he found the Jewish empowerment embodied by Israeli soldiers exciting, "So, I became deeply enamored of Israel because of that." He attended the [[University of Pennsylvania]], where he was editor-in-chief of ''[[The Daily Pennsylvanian]]''.{{cite book|title=Prisoners: A Muslim and a Jew Across the Middle East Divide|last=Goldberg|first=Jeffrey|publisher=Knopf|year=2006|isbn=0-375-41234-4|location=New York|page=41}} While at Penn he worked at the [[Hillel: The Foundation for Jewish Campus Life|Hillel]] kitchen serving lunch to students. He left college to move to [[Israel]], where he served in the [[Israeli Defense Forces]] as a prison guard during the [[First Intifada]] at [[Ktzi'ot Prison]], a prison camp set up to hold arrested Palestinian participants in the uprising. There he met Rafiq Hijazi, a [[Palestine Liberation Organization]] leader, college math teacher and devout Muslim from a refugee camp in the [[Gaza Strip]], whom Goldberg describes as "the only Palestinian I could find in Ketziot who understood the moral justification for Zionism". Goldberg lives in [[Washington, D.C.]], with his wife, Pamela (née Ress) Reeves, and their three children.{{cite web|url=http://www.randomhouse.com/knopf/ksb/speaker.php?sid=50|title=Knopf Speakers Bureau: Jeffrey Goldberg|accessdate=April 7, 2007}} ==Career== Goldberg returned to the [[United States]] and began his career at ''[[The Washington Post]]'', where he was a police reporter. While in Israel, he worked as a columnist for ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'', and upon his return to the US served as the New York bureau chief of ''[[The Forward]]'', a contributing editor at ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine, and a contributing writer at ''[[The New York Times Magazine]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.jeffreygoldberg.net/about/bio|title=About Jeffrey Goldberg|publisher=Personal website|accessdate=April 9, 2007}} In October 2000, Goldberg joined ''[[The New Yorker]].'' In 2007, he was hired by [[David G. Bradley]] to write for ''[[The Atlantic]]''. Bradley had tried to convince Goldberg to come work for ''The Atlantic'' for nearly two years, and was finally successful after renting ponies for Goldberg's children.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/08/05/AR2007080501576.html|title=The Atlantic's Owner Ponies Up|date=August 6, 2007|work=[[The Washington Post]]|author=[[Howard Kurtz]]|accessdate=August 18, 2007}} In 2011, Goldberg joined ''[[Bloomberg View]]'' as a columnist,{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/bios/jeffrey-goldberg|title=Jeffrey Goldberg: Articles & Columns|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=November 25, 2013}} and his editorials are also syndicated online, often appearing on such media sites as ''[[Newsday]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.newsday.com/opinion/oped/goldberg-barack-obama-achieves-half-of-his-iran-goals-1.6493916|title=Goldberg: Barack Obama achieves half of his Iran goals|last=Goldberg|first=Jeffrey|publisher=Newsday|accessdate=November 25, 2013}} and [[Newsmax]].{{cite web|url=http://www.newsmax.com/Insiders/Jeffrey-Goldberg/id-210|title=Middle East and Beyond|last=Goldberg|first=Jeffrey|publisher=Newsmax|accessdate=November 1, 2015}} Goldberg concluded writing for Bloomberg in 2014.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/contributors/AQdic_yTS8g/jeffrey-goldberg/articles|title=Bloomberg View article list|website=Bloomberg|accessdate=2017-01-15}} Goldberg was a journalist with ''The Atlantic'' before becoming editor-in-chief.{{cite news|last1=Ember|first1=Sidney|title=Atlantic Names Jeffrey Goldberg Its Editor in Chief|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/12/business/atlantic-is-expected-to-name-jeffrey-goldberg-its-editor-in-chief.html?_r=0|accessdate=October 11, 2016|website=The New York Times}} Goldberg wrote principally on foreign affairs, with a focus on the [[Middle East]] and [[Africa]].{{cite web|url=//www.newyorker.com/main/contributors/contribs_gk?contribs_gk |title=Contributors |accessdate=April 9, 2007 |publisher=The New Yorker |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061114014539/http://www.newyorker.com/main/contributors/contribs_gk?contribs_gk |archivedate=November 14, 2006 |df= }} [[Michael Massing]], an editor of the ''[[Columbia Journalism Review]]'', called Goldberg "the most influential journalist/blogger on matters related to Israel,"[[Michael Massing]], "[http://www.nybooks.com/articles/22960 The News About the Internet]", ''[[New York Book Review]]'' Volume 56, Number 13 (August 13, 2009). and [[David Rothkopf]], the CEO and editor of the [[Foreign Policy|FP Group]], called him "one of the most incisive, respected foreign policy journalists around."{{Cite web|title=In Search of the Real Barack Obama|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2015/06/01/in-search-of-the-real-barack-obama-jewish-president-jeffrey-goldberg|website=Foreign Policy|accessdate=2016-01-22}} He has been described by critics as a [[Neoconservatism|neoconservative]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2009/02/20/goldberg_3|title=Jeffrey Goldberg’s gasping, dying smear tactics|last=Greenwald|first=Glenn|website=Salon|access-date=2016-03-10}} a [[liberalism|liberal]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2008/05/a-jew-of-the-liberal-breed/8310/|title=A Jew of the Liberal Breed|last=Goldberg|first=Jeffrey|website=The Atlantic|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-10}} a [[Zionism|Zionist]]{{Cite web|url=http://nymag.com/news/features/peter-beinart-2012-6/|title=The Israeli Desert|website=NYMag.com|access-date=2016-03-10}} and a critic of Israel.{{Cite web|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/us-jewrys-bad-boy/?fb_comment_id=10151228785289692_27144512#f2a2224e98|title=US Jewry’s bad boy|website=The Times of Israel|accessdate=2016-03-10}} ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that he "shaped" the magazine's endorsement of [[Hillary Clinton]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 United States presidential election]], only the third endorsement in the magazine's 160-year history. ==Notable articles== {{Like resume|section|date=March 2016}} ==="The Great Terror", ''The New Yorker'', 2002=== In "The Great Terror", Goldberg investigates the nature of the Iraqi Army's chemical attack on the Kurds in [[Halabja chemical attack|Halabja]] in 1988 that resulted in the deaths of between 3,200 and 5,000 people and injured 7,000 to 10,000 more, most of them civilians.{{cite news|last=Goldberg|first=Jeffrey|title=The Great Terror|work=[[The New Yorker]]|date=March 25, 2002|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2002/03/25/the-great-terror|accessdate=July 29, 2014}}{{Cite news|title=1988: Thousands die in Halabja gas attack|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/march/16/newsid_4304000/4304853.stm|newspaper=BBC|date=1988-03-16|accessdate=2016-01-22}} "The Great Terror" won the [[Overseas Press Club]]'s Joe & Laurie Dine Award for international human rights reporting. In a March 2002 CNN interview, former [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] director, [[R. James Woolsey, Jr.|James Woolsey]] said, "I think Jeff Goldberg's piece is quite remarkable, and he and The New Yorker deserve a lot of credit for it."{{Cite web|title=Transcripts|url=http://www.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0203/23/tt.00.html|website=cnn.com|accessdate=2016-01-22}} ==="In the Party of God", ''The New Yorker'', 2002=== In October 2002, Goldberg wrote a two-part examination of [[Hezbollah]], "In the Party of God."{{Cite news|title=In the Party of God|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2002/10/14/in-the-party-of-god|newspaper=The New Yorker|date=2002-10-14|accessdate=2016-01-21|issn=0028-792X|first=Jeffrey|last=Goldberg}} Part I recounts his time in the village of Ras al-Ein, located in [[Lebanon]]'s [[Beqaa Valley|Bekaa Valley]], meeting with Hezbollah officials, including [[Mohammad Hussein Fadlallah]], Hezbollah's former spiritual leader, and [[Husayn Al-Musawi|Hussayn al-Mussawi]], founder of the now-defunct pro-Iranian Islamist militia [[Islamic Amal]] in 1982. Part II examines Hezbollah's activities in South America, specifically in the area known as the [[Triple Frontier]], a [[Tripoint|tri-border]] area along the junction of [[Paraguay]], [[Argentina]], and [[Brazil]]."{{Cite news|title=In the Party of God|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2002/10/28/in-the-party-of-god-2|newspaper=The New Yorker|date=2002-10-28|accessdate=2016-01-21|issn=0028-792X|first=Jeffrey|last=Goldberg}} In 2003, "In the Party of God" won the [[National Magazine Award]] for reporting.Jeffrey Goldberg, [http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2002/10/14/in-the-party-of-god "In the Party of God, Part One"], ''[[The New Yorker]]'' October 14 and October 21, 2003; accessed January 22, 2007.[http://www.newyorker.com/fact/content/articles/021028fa_fact2 "In the Party of God, Part Two"], ''[[The New Yorker]]'', October 28, 2003; accessed January 22, 2007; searchable database for [[National Magazine Award]]s on the website of the [[American Society of Magazine Editors]] (2003) ==="The Hunted", ''The New Yorker'', 2010=== In April 2010, Goldberg published "The Hunted", a ''[[The New Yorker|New Yorker]]'' article on Mark and Delia Owens, a conservationist couple based in [[Zambia]], who resorted to vigilantism in an effort to stop elephant poachers in North Luangwa National Park.{{Cite news|title=The Hunted|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2010/04/05/the-hunted|newspaper=The New Yorker|date=2010-04-05|accessdate=2016-01-21|issn=0028-792X|first=Jeffrey|last=Goldberg}} Goldberg chronicles the Owens’ attempts to counter the poachers’ activity in Zambia in the 1970s/80s, which began with creating incentives such as bounty programs for the park’s scouts, but as the poaching continued, the Owenses methods turned more confrontational. ''[[New York Times]]'' columnist [[Ross Douthat]] praised ''"The Hunted"'', noting that “Goldberg builds an extensive, persuasive case that the Owenses' much-lauded environmental activism in the Zambian hinterland led to at least one murder, and maybe more.”{{Cite web|title=A Killing in Zambia|url=http://douthat.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/04/15/a-killing-in-zambia|website=Ross Douthat|accessdate=2016-01-21}} ==="The Point of No Return", ''The Atlantic'', 2010=== In September 2010, Goldberg wrote the cover story for ''The Atlantic'', which examined the potential consequences of an Israeli attack on Iran's nuclear facilities.{{Cite web|title=The Point of No Return|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2010/09/the-point-of-no-return/308186|website=The Atlantic|accessdate=2016-01-21|language=en-US|first=Jeffrey|last=Goldberg}} Based on his interviews with high level Israeli and American government and military officials, including, [[Benjamin Netanyahu]], [[Shimon Peres]], [[Efraim Sneh|Ephraim Sneh]], [[Ben Rhodes (White House staffer)|Ben Rhodes]], [[Rahm Emanuel]], and [[Denis McDonough]], Goldberg writes, "I have come to believe that the administration knows it is a near-certainty that Israel will act against Iran soon if nothing or no one else stops the nuclear program; and Obama knows—as his aides, and others in the State and Defense departments made clear to me—that a nuclear-armed Iran is a serious threat to the interests of the United States, which include his dream of a world without nuclear weapons." After reading the article, [[Fidel Castro]] invited Goldberg to [[Cuba]] to talk about the issue.{{Cite web|title=Castro: 'No One Has Been Slandered More Than the Jews'|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2010/09/castro-no-one-has-been-slandered-more-than-the-jews/62566|website=The Atlantic|accessdate=2016-01-21|language=en-US|first=Jeffrey|last=Goldberg}} Goldberg published a series of articles on their interviews, including his views on anti-Semitism and Iran, Soviet-style Communism,{{Cite web|title=Fidel: 'Cuban Model Doesn't Even Work for Us Anymore'|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2010/09/fidel-cuban-model-doesnt-even-work-for-us-anymore/62602|website=The Atlantic|accessdate=2016-01-21|language=en-US|first=Jeffrey|last=Goldberg}} and theories on President [[John F. Kennedy]]'s assassination{{Cite web|title=Castro: 'Oswald Could Not Have Been the One Who Killed Kennedy'|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2013/11/castro-oswald-could-not-have-been-the-one-who-killed-kennedy/281674|website=The Atlantic|accessdate=2016-01-21|first=Jeffrey|last=Goldberg}} When asked by Goldberg if the Soviet-style Communism was still worth exporting, Castro famously replied that "the Cuban model doesn't even work for us anymore." ==="The Modern King in the Arab Spring", ''The Atlantic'', 2013=== In April 2013, Goldberg published an article on the Jordanian [[Abdullah II of Jordan|King Abdullah]] and his government's approach to reform in the wake of the [[Arab Spring|2011 protests]] around the Arab world.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2013/04/monarch-in-the-middle/309270|title=The Modern King in the Arab Spring|last=Goldberg|first=Jeffrey|website=The Atlantic|accessdate=2016-01-26}} In discussing a meeting between the King and the Jordanian tribes, Goldberg quotes the King as saying "I’m sitting with the old dinosaurs today.” This quote garnered a lot of controversy when published, and the King's Royal Court even issued a statement claiming the article contained many “fallacies” and that his words “were taken out of their correct context.”{{Cite web|title=King Abdullah chides Atlantic interviewer|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/king-abdullah-chides-atlantic-interviewer|website=The Times of Israel|accessdate=2016-01-22}} However, in defending the accuracy of his quotes, Goldberg later tweeted, "I just spoke to a top official of the Jordanian royal court. He said they are not contesting the accuracy of quotes in my Atlantic piece." ==="Is It Time for the Jews to Leave Europe?", ''The Atlantic'', 2015=== In April 2015, Goldberg published "Is It Time for the Jews to Leave Europe."{{Cite web|title=Is It Time for the Jews to Leave Europe?|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2015/04/is-it-time-for-the-jews-to-leave-europe/386279|website=The Atlantic|accessdate=2016-01-25|first=Jeffrey|last=Goldberg}} Goldberg's essay explores the state of the Jewish communities across Europe, especially in light of the resurgence of anti-Semitism and attacks against [[History of the Jews in Europe|Jews in Europe]].{{Cite news|title=Europe’s Anti-Semitism Comes Out of the Shadows|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/24/world/europe/europes-anti-semitism-comes-out-of-shadows.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=2014-09-23|accessdate=2016-01-25|issn=0362-4331|first=Jim|last=Yardley}}{{Cite news|title=Europe's Alarming New Anti-Semitism|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/europes-alarming-new-anti-semitism-1412270003|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=2016-01-25|issn=0099-9660|first=Jonathan|last=Sacks}} Historian [[Diana Pinto (historian)|Diana Pinto]], who is of Italian Jewish descent, wrote a rejoinder to Goldberg's article in ''[[The New Republic]]'', arguing that his article is excessively dire. She wrote: ''"''If a plaster cast may be permitted to speak, I would say that Goldberg and his colleagues aren’t describing my reality; the world I come from isn't already destroyed; and the story of the Jews in Europe isn’t yet ready to be relegated to museums or to antiquarian sites like Pompeii.''"''{{Cite web|title=I'm a European Jew—and No, I'm Not Leaving|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/121388/why-jews-arent-leaving-europe-contra-atlantics-jeffrey-goldberg|website=The New Republic|date=2015-03-27|accessdate=2016-01-25|first=Diana|last=Pinto}} ===President Barack Obama=== ====President Obama Interviews (2008, 2012, 2014, 2015, 2016)==== Goldberg has conducted five major interviews with President [[Barack Obama]] since 2008.{{Cite web|title=Obama on Zionism and Hamas|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2008/05/obama-on-zionism-and-hamas/8318/|website=The Atlantic|accessdate=2016-01-25|first=Jeffrey|last=Goldberg}}{{Cite web|title=Obama to Iran and Israel: 'As President of the United States, I Don't Bluff'|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2012/03/obama-to-iran-and-israel-as-president-of-the-united-states-i-dont-bluff/253875|website=The Atlantic|accessdate=2016-01-25|first=Jeffrey|last=Goldberg}}{{Cite web|title=Obama to Israel -- Time Is Running Out|url=http://www.bloombergview.com/articles/2014-03-02/obama-to-israel-time-is-running-out|website=BloombergView|date=2014-03-02|accessdate=2016-01-25}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2015/05/obama-interview-iran-isis-israel/393782|title=President Obama: The Middle East Interview|last=Goldberg|first=Jeffrey|website=The Atlantic|accessdate=2016-01-25}} Goldberg's interviews have centered around President Obama's views on [[Israel–United States relations|U.S.-Israel relations]], [[Zionism]], the 2015 [[Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action]], and other issues concerning U.S. foreign policy in the [[Middle East]] and [[North Africa]]. [[Peter Baker (author)|Peter Baker]], the [[White House]] correspondent for ''[[The New York Times]]'', recommended Goldberg's interviews with President Obama, writing, "For much of his time in office, President Obama has been having sort of a running conversation about the Middle East with Jeffrey Goldberg of ''The Atlantic'', one of the premier writers on the region based in Washington. In this latest interview, Mr. Obama defends his approach to the war against the Islamic State, warns Arab leaders not to pursue nuclear programs to match Iran and discusses his feud with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel. Along the way, Mr. Obama and Mr. Goldberg hash over the nature of the sometimes turbulent Israeli-American relationship."{{Cite web|title=What We’re Reading|url=http://news.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/05/22/what-were-reading-57|website=news.blogs.nytimes.com|accessdate=2016-01-26|first=The New York|last=Times}} ===="The Obama Doctrine", ''The Atlantic'', 2016==== In April 2016, Goldberg published ''The Obama Doctrine'', which was featured as the Atlantic's April 2016 cover story. This essay covers many foreign policy issues, including his views of the U.S. role in Asia, the Middle East, ISIS, Russia, and Europe, focusing on the nature of American leadership in these different regions and the relative power that the United States wields in developing and executing policies that reflect American interests abroad.{{Cite web|title=The Obama Doctrine|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2016/04/the-obama-doctrine/471525|website=The Atlantic|accessdate=2016-03-21|first=Jeffrey|last=Goldberg}} Goldberg's "The Obama Doctrine" was praised for its detailed accounting of the president's foreign policy views and sparked a debate about Obama's foreign policy legacy. Brian Katulis, a Senior Fellow at the [[Center for American Progress]], wrote in ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', "Jeffrey Goldberg’s analysis of President Barack Obama’s foreign policy (“The Obama Doctrine“) is required reading for those looking at the big picture on U.S. national security."{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2016/03/10/the-hole-in-the-obama-doctrine|title=The Hole in the 'Obama Doctrine'|last=Katulis|first=Brian|website=WSJ|accessdate=2016-03-22}} In a response piece in ''The Atlantic'', [[Martin Indyk]] praised the article, writing, "Jeffrey Goldberg’s fascinating article taps into President Obama's thinking about foreign policy and reveals its wellsprings. In that sense, he does more to help the president define and explain 'the Obama Doctrine' than previous efforts by the White House itself, captured in those memorable lines 'don’t do stupid shit' and 'leading from behind', which do not do justice to a doctrine that is both complicated and far-reaching in its implications for American foreign policy."{{Cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2016/03/obama-middle-east-policy/473529|title=The End of the U.S.-Dominated Order in the Middle East|last=Indyk|first=Martin|website=The "Realization of the humanity of the ‘other’ is at the heart of ''New Yorker'' magazine correspondent Jeffrey Goldberg's sharply observed and beautifully written memoir."{{Cite news|title=Common ground|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/oct/29/books/bk-ellenson29|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=2006-10-29|accessdate=2016-01-22|issn=0458-3035|first=Ruth Andrew|last=Ellenson}} ''[[The New York Times]]'' critic wrote, "Mr. Goldberg, a talented and ambitious writer for the ''New Yorker''...takes an engagingly personal approach to the issue in his story of a quest for mutual understanding with a Palestinian activist who had been his prisoner ... For the bittersweet complexity of that moment, offered in the context of all that has preceded it, this is a genuinely admirable book.”{{Cite web|title=Prisoners: A Muslim and a Jew Across the Middle East Divide|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/30/arts/30iht-bookmar.3332206.html|accessdate=2016-01-22}} ''[[The Washington Post]]'' review of the book noted, "''Prisoners'' is Jeffrey Goldberg’s sensitive, forthright and perceptive account of his years as a soldier and journalist in Israel—and of his long-running conversation with a Palestinian whom he once kept under lock and key. It is a forceful reminder of how rewarding, and how difficult, discourse between Israelis and Palestinians can be.”{{Cite news|title=The Hope|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/10/26/AR2006102601331.html|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=2006-10-29|accessdate=2016-01-22|issn=0190-8286|first=Reviewed by Haim|last=Watzman}} [[CBS News]] critic wrote, "There is no shortage of histories, polemics and policy manuals about the Middle East. An honest but complex story, from what happens to be a personal perspective that many Americans can at least conjure, is a rarer opportunity for insight. And that is what Jeffrey Goldberg, a reporter for The ''New Yorker'', delivers in ''Prisoners''. To those of us who have followed Jeffrey Goldberg’s reporting on the Muslim world, the publication of his first book is cause for real pleasure...because his writing on the subject has always been exceptional: wise, unpretentious, and at times, unexpectedly funny.”{{Cite web|title=Intellectual Journey: Through The Mideast|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/intellectual-journey-through-the-mideast|website=cbsnews.com|accessdate=2016-02-02}} Boris Kachka, a contributing editor for ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine, interviewed Goldberg in October 2006 about ''Prisoners'' in addition to other issues pertaining to journalism and the Middle East.{{Cite web|title=Brave Heart: Jeffrey Goldberg|url=http://nymag.com/arts/books/profiles/22294|website=NYMag.com|accessdate=2016-02-02}} ==Views on Iraq== In 2002, Goldberg's "The Great Terror" published in ''[[The New Yorker]]'' argued that the threat posed to America by [[Saddam Hussein]] was significant, discussing the possible connection between Saddam Hussein and [[Al Qaeda]] as well as the Iraqi nuclear program, averring that there was "some debate among arms-control experts about exactly when Saddam will have nuclear capabilities. But there is no disagreement that Iraq, if unchecked, will have them soon ... There is little doubt what Saddam might do with an atomic bomb or with his stocks of biological and chemical weapons." In a late 2002 debate in ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' on the question "Should the U.S. invade Iraq?", Goldberg argued in favor of an invasion on a moral basis, writing, "So: Saddam Hussein is uniquely evil, the only ruler in power today—and the first one since Hitler—to commit chemical genocide. Is that enough of a reason to remove him from power? I would say yes, if 'never again' is in fact actually to mean 'never again.'"{{Cite news|title=Should the U.S. Invade Iraq? Week 2|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/dialogues/features/2002/should_the_us_invade_iraq_week_2/aflatoxin.html|newspaper=Slate|date=2002-10-03|accessdate=2016-01-25|issn=1091-2339|first=Jeffrey|last=Goldberg}} [[Glenn Greenwald]] called Goldberg "one of the leading media cheerleaders for the attack on Iraq", claiming Goldberg had "compiled a record of humiliating falsehood-dissemination in the run-up to the war that rivaled [[Judith Miller|Judy Miller]]'s both in terms of recklessness and destructive impact."Greenwald, Glenn (July 27, 2010) [http://www.salon.com/2010/06/27/goldberg_7 "The Jeffrey Goldberg Media"], Salon.com; retrieved July 29, 2014. In 2008, in an article in ''Slate'' entitled "How Did I Get Iraq Wrong?", Goldberg explained the reasons behind his initial support of the Iraq War and wrote that he "didn't realize how incompetent the Bush administration could be."{{Cite news|title=How Did I Get Iraq Wrong?|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/politics/2008/03/how_did_i_get_iraq_wrong_5.html|newspaper=Slate|date=2008-03-19|accessdate=2016-01-25|issn=1091-2339|first=Jeffrey|last=Goldberg}} ==Bibliography== ===Books=== * ''Prisoners: A Muslim and a Jew Across the Middle East Divide''. {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Use British English|date=December 2017}} [[File:John Gilruth 1.jpg|thumb|240px|From left: [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Australia)|Minister]] [[Josiah Thomas]], [[Sir Walter Balfour Barttelot, 3rd Baronet|Sir Walter B. Barttelot]] and [[Administrator of the Northern Territory|Administrator]] John Gilruth in 1912.]] '''Dr John Anderson Gilruth''' {{Post-nominals|post-noms=[[Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh|FRSE]]}}<ref name="Waterston">{{cite book |last1=Waterston |first1=Charles D |last2=Macmillan Shearer |first2=A |title=Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783-2002: Biographical Index |url=http://www.rse.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp1.pdf |accessdate=8 December 2011 |volume=I |date=July 2006 |publisher=[[The Royal Society of Edinburgh]] |location=Edinburgh |isbn=978-0-902198-84-5}}</ref> (17 February 1871, [[Auchmithie]], [[Scotland]] – 4 March 1937, [[South Yarra]], [[Melbourne]]) was a [[Veterinary medicine|veterinary scientist]] and administrator. He is particularly noted for being [[Administrator of the Northern Territory]] from 1912 to 1918, when he was recalled after an angry mob demanded that he resign. This incident is known as the [[Darwin Rebellion]].
==Life== He was born in [[Auchmithie]] near [[Arbroath]] on 17 February 1871, the son of Andrew Gilruth.<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp1.pdf}}</ref>
He was educated at [[Arbroath High School]] and the [[High School of Dundee]], then served two years as clerk to an Arbroath solicitor before going to Glasgow Veterinary College, now the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine at the [[University of Glasgow]] in 1887. He was admitted to membership of the [[Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons]], [[London]], in 1892. He then accepted appointment as a government veterinary surgeon in [[New Zealand]].
In New Zealand from 1893, he spent three years investigating stock diseases, then a year at the [[Pasteur Institute]] in [[Paris]]. In 1896, on returning to New Zealand, he was appointed chief veterinarian and government [[Microbiology|bacteriologist]]. He was appointed a [[fellow]] of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]] in 1907. In 1908, he accepted the foundation chair of [[veterinary pathology]] at the [[University of Melbourne]].
In 1907 he was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]]. His proposers were [[Frederick Hobday]], Sir [[John McFadyean]], [[John Berry Haycraft]], and Sir [[Edward Albert Sharpey-Schafer]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp1.pdf}}</ref>
==Family==
He was married to Jennie McKay.
==Further reading==
* Alcorta, F. X. (1984). ''Darwin Rebellion''. Northern Territory University Planning Authority, Darwin {{OCLC|27546680}} * Jensen, H. I. (1966). ''The Darwin Rebellion''. Labour History, no 11, November 1966, pp 3–13. Canberra. {{OCLC|84284994}}
==References== {{Reflist}} *{{Australian Dictionary of Biography |last= Powell |first= Alan |authorlink= |year=1983 |id=A090017b |title= Gilruth, John Anderson (1871 - 1937) |accessdate=2008-03-26 }} * John Anderson Gilruth (2008). [http://www.nt.gov.au/administrator/pdf/cv/1912_gilruth.pdf Northern Territory Government Administrators]. Retrieved on 3 May 2008.
