'''Samuel Allardyce''' ({{IPAc-en|'|æ|l|ər|d|aɪ|s}}; born 19 October 1954) is an English [[association football|football]] manager and former professional player, who left his post as manager at [[Premier League]] club [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in May 2018.
Allardyce made 578 league and cup appearances in a 21-year career spent mostly in [[the Football League]], as well as brief spells in the [[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|North American Soccer League]] and [[League of Ireland]]. He was signed by [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] from [[Dudley Town F.C.|Dudley Town]] in 1969 and spent nine years at Bolton, helping the club to win the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] title in 1977–78. He spent the 1980s as a journeyman player, spending time with [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]], [[Tampa Bay Rowdies (1975–93)|Tampa Bay Rowdies]], [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]], [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]], Bolton Wanderers (for a second spell), [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]], and [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] (also working as assistant manager). During this time he helped Preston to win promotion out of the [[Football League Fourth Division|Fourth Division]] in 1986–87.
Moving into management, he took charge of Irish club [[Limerick F.C.|Limerick]] in 1991, leading the club to the [[League of Ireland First Division]] (second tier) title in 1991–92. He returned to England to coach at Preston North End, also serving briefly as caretaker-manager. He took up his first permanent management role in England at [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] in July 1994, but was sacked after two years having narrowly failed to achieve promotion. He spent January 1997 to October 1999 in charge at [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]], taking them to the [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]] title in 1997–98. He then returned to Bolton Wanderers as manager, leading the club to promotion out of the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] via the play-offs in 2001, as well as a [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] final and [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup]] qualification. Following a spell at [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] from May 2007 to January 2008, Allardyce managed [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] for a two-year spell from December 2008. He was appointed [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] manager in June 2011, leading the club to promotion out of the [[Football League Championship|Championship]] via the play-offs in 2012, before leaving West Ham in May 2015 after criticism from fans over his playing style. He was appointed [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] manager in October 2015 and saved the club from relegation. He was appointed as manager of the English national team for a brief spell in July 2016, before taking charge at [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] five months later. After helping Palace to avoid relegation that season, he announced his resignation in May 2017. He took charge at [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in November 2017 and remained in charge for a six-month period.
Allardyce has been labelled a [[long ball]] manager by some analysts, though he has disputed this perception as "totally and utterly wrong". He takes a modern, technology and statistics centred approach to tactics and coaching, and has been praised for his organisational and man-management skills.
Allardyce has been criticised for alleged corruption and has twice been the subject of undercover investigations. In September 2006, he and his son, [[Craig Allardyce|Craig]], were implicated in a [[BBC]] ''[[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]]'' documentary for taking bribes, allegations which they denied. In September 2016, undercover ''[[The Daily Telegraph|Daily Telegraph]]'' reporters posing as businessmen recorded him offering to help them to get around FA [[Third-party ownership in association football|third party ownership]] rules and provisionally agreeing a £400,000 contract.<ref name="Telegraph 270916">{{cite news|title=Sam Allardyce on the brink of being sacked as England manager after Telegraph investigation|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/09/27/sam-allardyces-position-as-england-manager-under-threat-after-te/|accessdate=27 September 2016|work=Daily Telegraph|date=27 September 2016}}</ref> Following [[2016 English football scandal|the ''Daily Telegraph'' investigation]], Allardyce resigned as England manager in a mutual agreement with [[the Football Association]] on 27 September.<ref name="SSN resignation">{{cite news|title=Sam Allardyce updates LIVE!|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/live-blog/12016/10595090/sam-allardyce-latest|accessdate=27 September 2016|agency=Sky Sports News|publisher=Sky|date=27 September 2016}}</ref>
==Early life== Samuel Allardyce was born in October 1954 on the Old Park Farm Estate, [[Dudley]], the son of Robert Allardyce (1916–1989) and Mary Agnes Allardyce (1918–1991). His father was a [[Sergeant#United Kingdom|police sergeant]].<ref name="telegraph1014">{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/west-ham/11186527/Sam-Allardyce-West-Hams-owners-are-best-Ive-ever-had-and-deserve-this-success-after-not-sacking-me.html | title=Sam Allardyce: West Ham's owners are best I've ever had and deserve this success after not sacking me | work=The Daily Telegraph | date=24 October 2014 | accessdate=26 October 2014 | author=Winter, Henry}}</ref> Both parents originated from Scotland with his father from [[Nairn]] and his mother from [[Dumfries]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=16}}</ref> He has an older sister, Mary, born in Scotland in 1939 and an older brother, Robert junior, born in 1951. Allardyce was educated at Sycamore Green Primary School and later at [[Defunct schools in the Metropolitan Borough of Dudley#Mons Hill School|Mons Hill School]], having been unsuccessful in his [[Eleven plus exam]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=18}}</ref> He discovered in later life that he suffers from [[dyslexia]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=11}}</ref> As a child, he supported [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] and dreamed that one day he would play at and manage the club.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/sports_talk/forum/1360531.stm | title=Q and A Bolton boss Sam Allardyce | publisher=BBC News | accessdate=10 April 2014}}</ref>
==Club career==
===Bolton Wanderers=== Allardyce spent his youth with semi-professional side [[Dudley Town F.C.|Dudley Town]], making his debut at the age of 14 he quickly learned how to play centre-half in the highly physical [[West Midlands (Regional) League]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=19}}</ref> He trained with local [[The Football League|Football League]] clubs [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] and Wolverhampton Wanderers, and had an unsuccessful trial with [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=20}}</ref> He was spotted by [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] just before leaving school at the age of 15, and signed an apprenticeship with the club.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=22}}</ref> To supplement his income before officially starting his apprenticeship he worked in a factory producing [[Phonograph|record decks]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=24}}</ref> The Bolton under-18s were very successful, winning the Lancashire Youth Cup and reaching the quarter-finals of the [[FA Youth Cup]], and Allardyce quickly rose through the B-team into the A-team.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=31}}</ref> He signed his first professional contract on his 17th birthday, receiving a £125 signing on fee and wages of £14 a week.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=32}}</ref>
Manager [[Jimmy Armfield]] gave Allardyce his debut for the "Trotters" on 6 November 1973, in a 2–1 defeat [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] to [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] at [[Burnden Park]].<ref name="page 34">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=34}}</ref> He made his [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] debut eleven days later, in a 2–1 defeat to [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]].<ref name="page 34"/> However he failed to establish himself in the first team under Armfield, and only got a run of games under new manager [[Ian Greaves]], who played Allardyce in the last ten games of the [[1974–75 Football League|1974–75]] season after he sold [[Don McAllister]] to [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=35}}</ref> He impressed during this short run, winning himself the club's Young Player of the Year award.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=36}}</ref>
Bolton lost to [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] after two replays in the [[FA Cup]] Fifth Round in the [[1975–76 Football League|1975–76]] season, and went on to miss out on promotion out of the league by a single point.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=40}}</ref> They suffered similar disappointment in the [[1976–77 Football League|1976–77]] campaign, reaching the semi-finals of the League Cup, and again finished just one point outside the promotion places.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=41}}</ref> Allardyce played alongside [[Paul Jones (footballer, born 1953)|Paul Jones]] at centre-half, and a scouting report for England manager [[Don Revie]] in 1977 described Allardyce and Jones as "one of the best central defensive pairings in the Football League." Despite this, however, he was never called up to the England team.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Winehouse|first1=Amitai|title=Sam Allardyce came close to winning England cap in 1977 when Don Revie sent scouts to watch him in action|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3769779/Sam-Allardyce-came-close-winning-England-cap-1977-Don-Revie-sent-scouts-watch-action.html|accessdate=18 October 2017|work=Daily Mail|date=2 September 2016}}</ref> Promotion was finally achieved in the [[1977–78 Football League|1977–78]] season, as Bolton returned to the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] as champions of the Second Division.<ref name="page 43">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=43}}</ref> Bolton consolidated their top-flight status with a 17th-place finish in [[1978–79 Football League|1978–79]].<ref name="page 44"/> However the [[1979–80 Football League|1979–80]] season proved difficult, and manager Greaves was sacked as the club went seven months without a league victory, whilst his replacement [[Stan Anderson]] was unable to steer the club away from relegation and a last-place finish.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=48}}</ref> Allardyce decided to leave Bolton at the end of the season as he felt that he was underpaid at Bolton and did not get on with Anderson.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=49}}</ref>
===Sunderland and Millwall=== Allardyce was offered a contract by [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] manager [[John Bond (footballer)|John Bond]], but the offer was bettered by [[Colin Addison]] at [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]], and he verbally agreed a three-year contract with Derby.<ref name="page 52">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=52}}</ref> However, before signing the contract he received a late offer from [[Ken Knighton]] to play for [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on a £300 a week contract with a £20,000 signing on fee – which more than quadrupled his wage at Bolton.<ref name="page 52"/> Allardyce signed for Sunderland on 1 July 1980 for £150,000.<ref>The Times - 2 July 1980</ref> Knighton appointed him as club captain.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=53}}</ref> However Allardyce soon wearied of the long-distance travel from [[Sunderland, Tyne and Wear|Sunderland]] to his home in [[Bolton]], and put in a transfer request when chairman [[Tom Cowie]] refused to help finance the purchase of a home in Sunderland.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=54}}</ref> Cowie sacked Knighton late in the [[1980–81 Football League|1980–81]] season, leaving caretaker manager [[Mick Docherty]] in charge to steer the club out of the First Division relegation zone.<ref name="page 55">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=55}}</ref> New manager [[Alan Durban]] left Allardyce out of the team at the start of the [[1981–82 Football League|1981–82]] campaign, leaving Allardyce's departure from [[Roker Park]] inevitable.<ref name="page 55"/>
He was offered the chance to return to Bolton Wanderers, but manager [[George Mulhall]] was only able to offer 50% of Allardyce's wages at Sunderland.<ref name="page 55"/> Instead he made a surprise £95,000 move to [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]] side [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]], who were able to match Sunderland's wages and also pay out a £30,000 signing on fee and a £10,000 loyalty bonus.<ref name="page 55"/> Millwall player-manager [[Peter Anderson (footballer, born 1949)|Peter Anderson]] had seen Allardyce as the successor to long-serving central defender [[Barry Kitchener]], and as Anderson was also a property developer he allowed Allardyce to live rent free in a six-bedroom mansion.<ref name="page 55"/> The "Lions" ended the 1981–82 season in mid-table, and Anderson was sacked in November 1982.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=57}}</ref> Chairman Alan Thorne offered Allardyce the vacant management position, but Allardyce rejected the offer as he felt that at aged 28 he was far too young to enter management.<ref name="page 58">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=58}}</ref> Instead it was [[George Graham (footballer)|George Graham]] who took up his first management position, and Graham immediately froze Allardyce out of the first team on both matchdays and training after Allardyce insisted that he would not report teammates who broke Graham's rules.<ref name="page 58"/> He came close to joining [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] on a free transfer in March 1983, but Charlton boss [[Lennie Lawrence]] did not complete the move before the end of the transfer deadline.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=59}}</ref> Graham agreed to pay Allardyce £15,000 to cancel his contract, acting under the assumption that Allardyce would struggle to find a club willing to offer him £300 a week.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=62}}</ref>
===Later career=== Allardyce wrote to every club in the top two divisions to inform them he was available on a free transfer, and privately lamented choosing his past clubs for financial rather than footballing reasons.<ref name="page 60">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=60}}</ref> Over the summer he played 11 games in the [[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|North American Soccer League]] for the [[Tampa Bay Rowdies (1975–93)|Tampa Bay Rowdies]], a club that shared facilities with the [[National Football League|NFL]]'s [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]].<ref name="nasl_profile">{{cite web | url = http://www.nasljerseys.com/Players/A/Allardyce.Sam.htm | title = Sam Allardyce | work = NASL Player Profile | accessdate =17 December 2008 }}</ref> Allardyce subsequently applied in his managerial career many modern practices of [[American football]] with regards to training, player management and tactics.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/premier_league/article5207738.ece |title=Sam Allardyce awaits his next big calling |work=The Times |date=22 November 2008 |accessdate=17 December 2008 |location=London |last=Rudd |first=Alyson}}</ref> He found playing difficult however, due to the heat and the all-out attacking nature of his teammates, which led to him being frequently exposed at the back, though he found that the club's masseurs managed to cure a long-standing [[hamstring]] scar tissue problem.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=64}}</ref>
Upon returning to the UK he joined [[Bobby Gould]]'s First Division [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] on a one-year £300 a week contract.<ref name="page 60"/> He was made captain, and though Coventry enjoyed a good first half to the [[1983–84 Football League|1983–84]] season they faltered badly in the second half of the season and finished just one place and two points above the relegation zone after beating Norwich City on the final day of the season.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=69}}</ref> Midway through the campaign Gould had promised him a new two-year contract, but following the poor end to the season he instead opted to release Allardyce.<ref name="page 70">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=70}}</ref>
In July 1984, he was signed by [[Mick Buxton]] at Second Division [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]].<ref name="page 70"/> The move reunited him with [[Paul Jones (footballer, born 1953)|Paul Jones]], his former centre-half partner at Bolton.<ref name="page 71">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=71}}</ref> Huddersfield finished in 13th place in the [[1984–85 Huddersfield Town A.F.C. season|1984–85]] season, and at the end of the campaign accepted an offer of £15,000 from Bolton Wanderers, who offered Allardyce a three-year contract.<ref name="page 71"/> Bolton were then managed by [[Charlie Wright]], who was the goalkeeper at Allardyce's first spell with the club.<ref name="page 71"/> However Wright was sacked in December 1985, and his successor, [[Phil Neal]], did not get along with Allardyce.<ref name="page 71"/> Neal played himself at centre-half and relegated Allardyce to the bench, despite Neal being a full-back.<ref name="page 71"/> Bolton reached the [[1986 Football League Trophy Final]] at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]], which ended in a 3–0 defeat to [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]], with Allardyce as an unused substitute.<ref name="page 72">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=72}}</ref>
Allardyce was offered the chance to join [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]], but instead joined [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] after being persuaded by manager [[John McGrath (footballer, born 1938)|John McGrath]], who promised to make Allardyce the backbone of his team.<ref name="page 72"/> Preston won promotion out of the [[Football League Fourth Division|Fourth Division]] in second-place in [[1986–87 Football League|1986–87]] (Allardyce was also named on the [[PFA Team of the Year]]), and consolidated their Third Division status with a 16th-place finish in [[1987–88 Football League|1987–88]].<ref name="Lynch 140">{{Cite book| first = Tony| last = Lynch| title = The Official P.F.A. Footballers Heroes| year = 1995| publisher = Random House| isbn = 0-09-179135-9| page = 146 }}</ref><ref name="page 76">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=76}}</ref> By this time Allardyce began considering his retirement as a player, and applied to management positions at [[York City F.C.|York City]] and [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]], and had an unsuccessful interview with [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]].<ref name="page 76"/>
==Style of play== Bolton fans gave him the nickname "Super Sam [[Steve Austin (character)|Bionic Man]]" due to his tough tackling approach and the way he quickly got up after heavy collisions whilst the opposition player would be left flat on the ground.<ref name="page 37">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=37}}</ref> Veteran manager [[Dave Bassett]], a friend of Allardyce, once humorously remarked that "He was what I called a ball-playing defender... If he wasn't playing with the ball he was playing with your balls."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2001/feb/13/newsstory.sport3 |title=Bolton buzzing again as Allardyce builds for future |last1=Taylor |first1=Daniel |date=13 February 2001 |website=[[theguardian.com]] |accessdate=4 May 2016}}</ref> He was uncomfortable in possession, and played simple balls to his nearest teammates when he found himself with the ball, whilst teammates would be reluctant to pass to him.<ref name="page 37"/> He did however possess good awareness and heading skills, and his anticipation made up for his lack of pace.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=38}}</ref>
==Managerial career==
===Early career=== Allardyce was hired as a player-coach by [[Brian Talbot]] at [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] in February 1989.<ref name="Times020105">Walsh, David; [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/article407620.ece "The Big Interview: Sam Allardyce"] [[The Times|''TimesOnline.co.uk'']], 2 January 2005 (Retrieved 25 July 2009)</ref> He spent most of the rest of the [[1988–89 Football League|1988–89]] season at [[The Hawthorns]] managing and playing for the reserve team, before being promoted to first team coach in the summer, in a move that saw former first team coach [[Stuart Pearson]] demoted to reserve team coaching.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=79}}</ref> Allardyce and Talbot were sacked in January 1991 following a defeat to [[Isthmian League]] side [[Woking F.C.|Woking]] in the [[FA Cup]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=81}}</ref> He later worked as a part-time coach at [[Bury F.C.|Bury]], but manager [[Mike Walsh (footballer)|Mike Walsh]] could not afford to keep him on the staff for the [[1989–90 Football League|1989–90]] season.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=85}}</ref>
Allardyce then took up the role of player-manager of [[Limerick F.C.|Limerick]], and guided the team to promotion into the [[League of Ireland Premier Division]] after winning the [[1991–92 League of Ireland First Division]]. They achieved promotion despite tremendous financial pressures, with Allardyce coaching and playing for the first team whilst the club board signed players as Allardyce had no knowledge of the Irish football scene.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=90}}</ref>
After his season in Ireland, Allardyce returned to England for the start of the [[1992–93 Football League|1992–93]] season to coach at [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] under [[Les Chapman]].<ref name="page 92">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=92}}</ref> Ten games into the season, however, Chapman was sacked and Allardyce was appointed [[caretaker manager]].<ref name="page 92"/> Despite a promising spell in charge, Allardyce did not get the job on a permanent basis, and in December 1992 Preston appointed [[John Beck (footballer)|John Beck]] as manager.<ref name="page 93">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=93}}</ref> Allardyce worked as youth team coach for 18 months, but later said the extreme [[long ball]] tactics Beck enforced upon the club were "indefensible".<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=95}}</ref>
===Blackpool=== On 19 July 1994<ref>The Times 20 July 1994</ref> [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]], [[West Lancashire derby]] rivals to Preston North End, appointed Allardyce as their new manager following the departure of [[Billy Ayre]], agreeing a salary of £18,000 a year.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=98}}</ref> He signed defender [[Darren Bradshaw]], midfielder [[Micky Mellon]] and spent a club record £245,000 on [[Andy Morrison]], who Allardyce described as a "horrible in-your-face" centre-back and a "complete nutter".<ref name="page 99">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=99}}</ref> He also changed the club's backroom staff, hiring [[Bobby Saxton]] as his assistant, promoting player [[Phil Brown (footballer, born 1959)|Phil Brown]] to a coaching role, and appointing [[Mark Taylor (footballer, born 1964)|Mark Taylor]] as physio, who would follow Allardyce to Blackburn and Newcastle.<ref name="page 100">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=100}}</ref> Blackpool finished the [[1994–95 Blackpool F.C. season|1994–95]] season in 12th place after falling out of the promotion race with just one win in their final 11 games.<ref name="page 100"/>
He spent £200,000 on striker [[Andy Preece]], and also brought in young defender [[Jason Lydiate]] and goalkeeper [[Steve Banks (footballer)|Steve Banks]] for the [[1995–96 Blackpool F.C. season|1995–96]] campaign.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=101}}</ref> Blackpool finished third, missing out on automatic promotion on the last day of the season, and were beaten in the play-off semi-finals by [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=102}}</ref> They had won 2–0 away at [[Valley Parade]], only to lose 3–0 in the return leg at [[Bloomfield Road]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.fchd.info/BLACKPOO.HTM | title = Blackpool | accessdate =17 December 2008 | publisher = Football Club History Database}}</ref> Chairman [[Owen Oyston]], while he was in a prison cell, sacked Allardyce shortly after the play-off defeat.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/football/2006/mar/19/sport.comment | title = Is Sam the big man for England? |work=The Guardian | date = 19 March 2006 | location=London | first=Jamie | last=Jackson}}</ref> Allardyce then had a brief spell on the coaching staff under [[Peter Reid]] at [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], working as director of the [[Sunderland A.F.C. Reserves and Academy|academy]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/s/sunderland/7766413.stm |title=Allardyce keen on Sunderland post |publisher=BBC News |date=9 December 2008 |accessdate=27 May 2011}}</ref>
{{quote|We had missed promotion to the First Division by a point. Yet it had all been done on next-to-nothing, and during the months leading towards the end of the season, I hardly ever saw Owen Oyston. But he always assured me that, no matter what, my job would be safe. I turned up for that meeting having been told it was to discuss new terms. Instead, I was told that I was being sacked. It was cold, calculated, pre-planned, whatever. I walked out of there with ₤10,000, no job, and desperately worried that my reputation would be damaged forever.|Five years after his sacking, Allardyce stated that he still had no idea why Blackpool relieved him of his position.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/1323484.stm | title = The pressure of the play-offs |publisher=BBC | date = 10 May 2001 | accessdate =17 December 2008 }}</ref><ref name=Gillatt>{{cite book|last=Gillatt|first=Peter|title=Blackpool FC On This Day: History, Facts and Figures from Every Day of the Year |publisher=Pitch Publishing Ltd|date=30 November 2009|isbn=1-905411-50-2}}</ref>}}
===Notts County=== In January 1997, Allardyce made his return to football as manager of struggling Division Two club [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=111}}</ref> He arrived too late to save them from relegation in [[1996–97 Notts County F.C. season|1996–97]], and in his autobiography described how the players "would not respond" to his coaching methods as they went 18 games without a win and pressure mounted on Allardyce.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=112}}</ref> However he held on to his job, and led the club to promotion as champions of Division Three at the end of the [[1997–98 Football League|1997–98]] season, built upon a three-man defence and a mid-season run of ten consecutive wins.<ref name="page 114">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=114}}</ref> County broke several club and national records, winning the title by a 19-point margin and becoming the first post-war side to win promotion in March.<ref name="page 114"/>
Despite the success, chairman Derek Pavis refused to spend money on transfers, and as a result fell out with Allardyce.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=115}}</ref> Allardyce was eventually allowed to spend £50,000 on striker [[Kevin Rapley]], who helped the club to steer clear of relegation at the end of the [[1998–99 Football League|1998–99]] campaign.<ref name="page 116">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=116}}</ref> In the summer he signed midfielder [[Craig Ramage]] and utility player [[Clayton Blackmore]].<ref name="page 116"/> Allardyce remained in charge at [[Meadow Lane]] until 14 October 1999, when he resigned his post at Notts County to return to Bolton Wanderers.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=125}}</ref>
===Bolton Wanderers===
====Promotion out of Division One==== Allardyce was appointed manager of Bolton Wanderers following [[Colin Todd]]'s departure, who had resigned in protest at the sale of [[Per Frandsen]] as the club attempted to raise funds for the new [[Macron Stadium|Reebok Stadium]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=123}}</ref> He inherited a talented squad, which included [[Eiður Guðjohnsen]], [[Jussi Jääskeläinen]], [[Mark Fish]], [[Claus Jensen]], [[Dean Holdsworth]], [[Bo Hansen]], [[Michael Johansen]], and [[Ricardo Gardner]].<ref name="page 127">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=127}}</ref> However he was forced to sell [[Andy Todd (footballer, born 1974)|Andy Todd]], son of Colin Todd, after he broke assistant manager Phil Brown's jaw in a team bonding session.<ref name="page 127"/> Despite being in the bottom half of the table when he took over, Bolton reached the [[1999–2000 Bolton Wanderers F.C. season|1999–2000]] Division One play-offs, losing to [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]], and had an eventful run to the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] and [[FA Cup]] semi-finals, only missing out on the [[2000 FA Cup Final]] after a penalty shoot-out defeat to [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=129}}</ref> He blamed referee [[Barry Knight (referee)|Barry Knight]] for the play-off defeat, who he accused of being biased against Bolton.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=132}}</ref> Allardyce was rewarded for turning the club around with a ten-year contract, though the terms of the contract only entitled him to a one year's compensation pay if he was sacked.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=130}}</ref>
In summer 2000, Guðjohnsen and Jensen were sold for £4 million each.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=133}}</ref> Allardyce focused on spending money to improve the club's facilities and backroom staff, believing that money spent in these areas would allow Bolton to compete with clubs who had bigger budgets and paid bigger wages than Bolton could afford.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=134}}</ref> On the playing front he spent £400,000 on striker [[Michael Ricketts]] and £1.5 million to bring back Frendsen from Blackburn, and also signed utility player [[Ian Marshall (English footballer)|Ian Marshall]] and [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]] loanee [[Isaiah Rankin]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=136}}</ref> Teenager [[Kevin Nolan]] was also promoted from the youth team, whilst 35-year-old defender [[Colin Hendry]] arrived on loan.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=137}}</ref> Bolton reached the [[2001 Football League First Division play-off Final|play-off final]] at the [[Millennium Stadium]] in [[2000–01 Bolton Wanderers F.C. season|2000–01]], where they beat [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] 3–0 to achieve promotion to the [[Premier League]] after a three-year absence.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=142}}</ref>
====Premier League survival==== Building for the [[2001–02 Bolton Wanderers F.C. season|2001–02]] Premier League campaign, Allardyce signed [[France national football team|France]] international defender [[Bruno N'Gotty]] from [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] in a loan deal which was eventual made into a permanent one after N'Gotty established himself as a key first team player.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=145}}</ref> He also brought in [[Henrik Pedersen]] from [[Silkeborg IF]] for £650,000, though otherwise remained loyal to the players that had won promotion the previous campaign.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bolton_wanderers/1420715.stm |title=Bolton snap up Pedersen |date=3 July 2001 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=26 September 2011 }}</ref> They recorded a 5–0 win at [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] on the opening day, then beat [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] and [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] to secure nine points from their first three games.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=149}}</ref> After six games without a win, Bolton then recorded a shock 2–1 victory over [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] on 20 October.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=151}}</ref> However their form dropped, and so in the January transfer window Allardyce brought in Danish midfielder [[Stig Tøfting]], German striker [[Fredi Bobic]] (on loan), and [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]]-winning attacker [[Youri Djorkaeff]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=152}}</ref> Djorkaeff scored both goals in a 2–1 win over [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] on 23 March and Bobic scored a hat-trick in a 4–1 win over Ipswich Town on 6 April; the victory over Ipswich proved to be essential as Bolton ended the season in 16th place on 40 points, ahead of Ipswich who were relegated with 36 points.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=153}}</ref>
Allardyce manage to sign another big name on a free transfer for the [[2002–03 Bolton Wanderers F.C. season|2002–03]] season, bringing in 28-year-old [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] captain [[Jay-Jay Okocha]], who four years previously had been purchased by [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]] for £14 million.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=156}}</ref> He also brought in Spanish central defender [[Iván Campo]] on loan from [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=157}}</ref> He sold 2001–02 top-scorer [[Michael Ricketts]] to Middlesbrough for £3.5 million, bringing in [[Pierre-Yves André]] on loan as his replacement.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=161}}</ref> Bolton struggled all season, but managed to avoid relegation with a final day win over Middlesbrough.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bolton seal survival|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/2978087.stm|accessdate=2 April 2016|publisher=BBC Sport|date=11 May 2003}}</ref>
Looking to avoid another relegation battle, Allardyce made a number of signings in preparation for the [[2003–04 Bolton Wanderers F.C. season|2003–04]] season, the most significant of which were Brazilian defender [[Emerson Thome]], [[Greece national football team|Greece]] international [[Stelios Giannakopoulos]], and target-man striker [[Kevin Davies]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=164}}</ref> Allardyce's side finished eighth in the league and reached the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] final, in what was his first major domestic final appearance as a player or manager.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=167}}</ref> Bolton lost [[2004 Football League Cup Final|2–1]] to [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] in the final, though Allardyce blamed referee [[Mike Riley (referee)|Mike Riley]] for not giving a late penalty for an alleged handball by [[Ugo Ehiogu]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=168}}</ref>
====Venture in Europe==== Now an established Premier League club, Bolton signed veteran internationals [[Gary Speed]] and [[Fernando Hierro]], aged 35 and 36 respectively.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=169}}</ref> Speed and Hierro went into midfield, while [[Tunisia national football team|Tunisia]] international [[Radhi Jaïdi]] was played at centre-back after arriving on a free transfer from [[Espérance Sportive de Tunis|Espérance]]; he was played alongside another new arrival, [[Israel national football team|Israel]] defender [[Tal Ben Haim]], who was recommended by Allardyce's son Craig.<ref name="page 170">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=170}}</ref> He also brought in [[Senegal national football team|Senegal]] striker [[El Hadji Diouf]] on a season-long loan from Liverpool, who he would eventually sign permanently for £3 million.<ref name="page 170"/> After a good start to the season, Allardyce was offered the Newcastle United job, but turned it down and instead signed a new five-year contract with Bolton as he felt the Bolton squad to be more talented.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=171}}</ref> Bolton went on to finish in sixth place in [[2004–05 Bolton Wanderers F.C. season|2004–05]] to win qualification to the [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup]] for the first time in the [[History of Bolton Wanderers F.C.|club's history]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=174}}</ref>
Bolton reached the Round of 32 in the UEFA Cup in [[2005–06 Bolton Wanderers F.C. season|2005–06]], beating [[PFC Lokomotiv Plovdiv|Lokomotiv Plovdiv]] ([[Bulgaria]]) in the First Round and successfully negotiating through the Group stage after beating [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg|Zenit Saint Petersburg]] (Russia), and drawing with [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] (Spain), [[Beşiktaş J.K.|Beşiktaş]] ([[Turkey]]) and [[Vitória S.C.|Vitória Guimarães]] ([[Portugal]]), before losing to Marseille (France) in the knock-out stages.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=186}}</ref> Allardyce's success with Bolton resulted in [[the Football Association|the FA]] putting him on a short-list of four people to succeed [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]] as [[England national football team|England]] [[England national football team manager|manager]] after the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]], alongside [[Alan Curbishley]], [[Steve McClaren]] and [[Martin O'Neill]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=189}}</ref> He was interviewed for the position and was told by FA Chief Executive [[Brian Barwick]] that the final choice would be between him and McClaren, however the FA eventually decided to give the job to McClaren.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=196}}</ref> Allardyce was also again offered the Newcastle job and was this time to keen to take it, but Newcastle chairman Freddie Shepard broke off contract negotiations after electing to appoint caretaker-manager [[Glenn Roeder]] on a full-time basis.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=199}}</ref> Allardyce's team seemed unaffected by speculation on his future or by their European exploits, and ended the season in eighth position.
Keen to strengthen Bolton for a European push in the [[2006–07 Bolton Wanderers F.C. season|2006–07]] season, Allardyce signed France international striker [[Nicolas Anelka]] from [[Fenerbahçe S.K. (football)|Fenerbahçe]] for a [[List of Bolton Wanderers F.C. records and statistics|club record]] £8 million.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=200}}</ref> He also signed [[Ivory Coast national football team|Ivory Coast]] defender [[Abdoulaye Méïté]] from Marseille, and in an unusual sequence of events made a £400,000 profit on [[Dietmar Hamann]], who changed his mind about joining Bolton and signed with [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] a day after signing a pre-contract agreement with Bolton; Manchester City agreed to pay Bolton £400,000 in compensation.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=201}}</ref> However Allardyce's relationship with chairman [[Phil Gartside]] became increasingly strained as Gartside refused to sanction greater transfer spending to finance a push for [[UEFA Champions League]] qualification.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=202}}</ref> On 29 April 2007, Allardyce resigned with the club in fifth place with two games of the season left to play, and the following day his assistant [[Sammy Lee (footballer)|Sammy Lee]] was announced as his replacement.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bolton_wanderers/6605673.stm | title = Allardyce resigns as Bolton boss |publisher=BBC | date = 29 April 2007 | accessdate =17 December 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bolton_wanderers/6606553.stm | title = Lee appointed manager of Bolton |publisher=BBC | date = 30 April 2007 | accessdate =17 December 2008 }}</ref>
===Newcastle United=== [[File:Sam Allardyce Airport.png|thumb|upright|Allardyce as manager of Newcastle United in 2007]]
Allardyce was offered the Manchester City job, but the offer was withdrawn after [[Thaksin Shinawatra]]'s purchase offer of the club was accepted.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=217}}</ref> On 15 May 2007, Newcastle United announced that Allardyce had signed a three-year contract to succeed Glenn Roeder as manager.<ref name="Newcastle name Allardyce as boss">{{cite news | title = Newcastle name Allardyce as boss | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/6654121.stm |publisher=BBC | date = 15 May 2007 | accessdate =17 December 2008}}</ref> Coincidentally Newcastle then also had a change of owners, as [[Mike Ashley (businessman)|Mike Ashley]] completed his takeover of the club.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=221}}</ref> The sales of [[Scott Parker]] and [[Kieron Dyer]] raised £13 million, allowing Allardyce to sign [[Australia national association football team|Australia]] international striker [[Mark Viduka]] (free transfer), utility man [[Alan Smith (footballer, born 1980)|Alan Smith]] (£6 million), midfielder [[Geremi Njitap]], controversial midfielder [[Joey Barton]] (£5.5 million), left-back [[José Enrique (footballer)|José Enrique]] (£6.3 million), right-back [[Habib Beye]] (£2 million), and defender [[Abdoulaye Faye]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=222}}</ref> Newcastle enjoyed a good start to the season, beating Allardyce's former club Bolton 3–1 on the opening day in a run of five wins and two draws from the opening nine league games.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=223}}</ref> However they then had a series of disappointing results in the run-up to Christmas, and after gaining only one point from a possible six from bottom-of-the-table Wigan and Derby.<ref>{{cite news | title = Newcastle 2–2 Derby |publisher=BBC | date = 23 December 2007 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7145755.stm | accessdate =17 December 2008 | first=Caroline | last=Cheese}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Wigan 1–0 Newcastle |publisher=BBC | date = 26 December 2007 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7157373.stm | accessdate =17 December 2008 | first=Jonathan | last=Stevenson}}</ref> Allardyce parted company with Newcastle United on 9 January 2008.<ref>{{cite news |title=Sam Allardyce Leaves Newcastle United FC |publisher=Newcastle United FC |date=9 January 2008 |url=http://www.nufc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10278~1210966,00.html |accessdate=17 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081222031607/http://www.nufc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10278~1210966%2C00.html |archivedate=22 December 2008 }}</ref> He had gone into the meeting with chairman [[Chris Mort]] expecting to be told Newcastle had signed a new player, not expecting that Ashley and Mort had decided to instead sign [[Kevin Keegan]] to return as manager.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=226}}</ref>
===Blackburn Rovers=== [[File:Old Trafford Technical Area Alex Ferguson Sam Allardyce.jpg|thumb|Allardyce (top) as manager of Blackburn Rovers in 2009]]
On 17 December 2008, Allardyce was appointed as manager of [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] on a three-year contract, succeeding [[Paul Ince]] who left the club in 19th place with just three wins from 17 games.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=228}}</ref> Allardyce's first game in charge was a 3–0 victory over [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] at [[Ewood Park]] three days later.<ref name="page 230">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=230}}</ref> This was the first game of a nine-game unbeaten run. He strengthened the team by spending £2 million on Sunderland winger [[El Hadji Diouf]] and brought in defender [[Gaël Givet]] on loan from Marseille.<ref name="page 230"/> Allardyce finished his first season in charge with a 0–0 draw with [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] and a final league position of 15th.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://espnfc.com/tables/_/league/eng.1/season/2008/barclays-premier-league?cc=3436 | title=2008–09 Premier League | publisher=ESPN | accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.11v11.com/matches/blackburn-rovers-v-west-bromwich-albion-24-may-2009-285163/ |title=Blackburn Rovers v West Bromwich Albion, 24 May 2009 |publisher=11v11.com |accessdate=1 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120613235600/http://www.11v11.com/matches/blackburn-rovers-v-west-bromwich-albion-24-may-2009-285163/ |archivedate=13 June 2012 }}</ref>
Blackburn were forced to sell talismanic [[Paraguay national football team|Paraguay]] striker [[Roque Santa Cruz]] to Manchester City and defender [[Stephen Warnock]] to Aston Villa for a combined £21.5 million to balance the books.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=231}}</ref> Allardyce was permitted to bring in defensive midfielder [[Steven Nzonzi]] from [[Amiens SC|Amiens]] for £500,000, [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]] international forward [[Nikola Kalinić]] from [[HNK Hajduk Split|Hajduk Split]] for £6 million, and [[Pascal Chimbonda]] from Tottenham Hotspur for £2.5 million.<ref>{{cite web | title= Rekordan transfer: Kalinić u Blackburnu! | publisher=HNK Hajduk Split | url=http://hajduk.hr/vijest/clanak/117 |date=3 August 2009| accessdate=3 August 2009| language=hr}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.rovers.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10303~1779869,00.html |title=Chimbonda joins Rovers |date=27 August 2009 |publisher=Blackburn Rovers F.C. |accessdate=27 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090829064034/http://www.rovers.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10303~1779869%2C00.html |archivedate=29 August 2009 }}</ref> In the [[2009–10 Blackburn Rovers F.C. season|2009–10]] season, Blackburn reached the League Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, but lost over two legs.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/league_cup/8466159.stm | title=Aston Villa 6 – 4 Blackburn (agg 7 – 4) | publisher=BBC Sport | date=20 January 2010 | accessdate=1 February 2014 | author=Henson, Mike}}</ref> Blackburn remained mid-table for the duration of the season, and finished tenth with a final day victory away at Aston Villa.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://espnfc.com/tables/_/league/eng.1/season/2009/barclays-premier-league?cc=3436 | title=2009–10 Premier League | publisher=ESPN | accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.11v11.com/matches/aston-villa-v-blackburn-rovers-09-may-2010-289783/ |title=Aston Villa 0–1 Blackburn Rovers |publisher=11v11.com |accessdate=1 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203021019/http://www.11v11.com/matches/aston-villa-v-blackburn-rovers-09-may-2010-289783/ |archivedate=3 February 2014 }}</ref>
The club was put up for sale in summer 2010, and Allardyce was offered the job of managing [[Al-Ahli Dubai F.C.|Al-Ahli Dubai]], but could not secure permission to leave Blackburn without paying compensation to the club and so remained in charge at [[Ewood Park]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=240}}</ref> Allardyce was later sacked by new owners the [[V H Group|Venky's]] on 13 December 2010, with Rovers placed 13th in the league.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/blackburn_rovers/9283395.stm | title=Blackburn Rovers sack manager Sam Allardyce | date=13 December 2010 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/dec/13/sam-allardyce-sacked-blackburn-rovers-manager|title=Sacked Blackburn manager Sam Allardyce 'shocked and disappointed'|date=13 December 2010|work=The Guardian |accessdate=13 December 2010|location=London|first=Andy|last=Hunter}}</ref> He was replaced by one of his coaches, [[Steve Kean]], whose agent [[Jerome Anderson (football agent)|Jerome Anderson]] was a highly influential figure with the Venky family.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=244}}</ref><ref name= "How an agent came to hold so much power at Blackburn Rovers">Conn, David. [https://www.theguardian.com/sport/david-conn-inside-sport-blog/2010/dec/21/blackburn-rovers-venkys-jerome-anderson "How an agent came to hold so much power at Blackburn Rovers"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 21 December 2010. Retrieved 2 August 2016.</ref><ref name= "Steve Kean finds value of friends in high places at Blackburn Rovers">Hytner, David. [https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2010/dec/16/steve-kean-blackburn-rovers "Steve Kean finds value of friends in high places at Blackburn Rovers"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 16 December 2010. Retrieved 2 August 2016.</ref>
===West Ham United=== [[File:Sam Allardyce Wet Ham sideline.jpg|thumb|left|Allardyce (right) as manager of West Ham United in 2011]]
Allardyce was appointed as manager of then-recently relegated [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] on 1 June 2011, signing a two-year contract.<ref>{{cite news | title = Sam's the man | publisher Allardyce's main signing of summer 2013 was Andy Carroll, for a £15 million fee from Liverpool, whilst he also spent an undisclosed fee on winger [[Stewart Downing]], again from Liverpool, to provide crosses for Carroll to convert into goals.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=278}}</ref> He also signed goalkeeper [[Adrián (footballer)|Adrián]] on a free transfer from [[Real Betis]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=306}}</ref> However Allardyce's plans were disrupted when Carroll picked up a long-term injury, which left Allardyce regretting the transfer, especially as he had chosen Carroll instead of signing [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]]'s [[Wilfried Bony]], who went on to score 16 league goals in the [[2013–14 West Ham United F.C. season|2013–14]] campaign.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=279}}</ref> Allardyce was awarded the [[Premier League Manager of the Month]] for February 2014 following a run of four wins and one draw in their five Premier League games.<ref name="2 2014 motm">{{cite web | url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11661/9212554/west-ham-boss-sam-allardyce-named-barclays-premier-league-manager-of-the-month | title=West Ham boss Sam Allardyce named Barclays Premier League Manager of the Month | publisher=Sky Sports | date=14 March 2014 | accessdate=21 October 2014 | author=Webb, Emma}}</ref> In April 2014, during an away game against West Bromwich Albion, a section of West Ham fans expressed their distaste at the style of football played under Allardyce by displaying a banner which read "Fat Sam Out, killing WHU".<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/fat-sam-out--west-ham-fans-hold-up-anti-sam-allardyce-banner-during-west-brom-loss-9292008.html | title="Fat Sam out" – West Ham fans hold up anti Sam Allardyce banner during West Brom loss | work=London Evening Standard | date=26 April 2014 | accessdate=27 April 2014 | location=London}}</ref> The following month some supporters hung a banner bearing the legend "Fat Sam Out" outside the mansion owned by club chairman, [[David Sullivan (businessman)|David Sullivan]], in [[Theydon Bois]], Essex.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/west-ham/10830200/West-Ham-owner-removes-Fat-Sam-Out-banner-from-outside-his-mansion-as-fans-voice-frustration-at-Allardyce.html | title=West Ham owner removes 'Fat Sam Out' banner from outside his mansion as fans voice frustration at Allardyce | work=The Daily Telegraph | date=14 May 2014 | accessdate=21 May 2014 | author=Law Matt | location=London}}</ref> Despite protests, on 20 May 2014, the club announced that Allardyce would be staying as manager and would be supported by new attacking coach [[Teddy Sheringham]] for the [[2014–15 West Ham United F.C. season|2014–15]] season to "ensure the team provides more entertainment" and to "improve the club's goal tally".<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/27357306 | title=Sam Allardyce: West Ham United announce manager is staying | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=21 May 2014}}</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27632489 "Teddy Sheringham returns to West Ham as attacking coach"] BBC Sport, 30 May 2014</ref> [[File:Allardyce May 2015.jpg|thumb|right|230px|Allardyce as West Ham United manager in 2015]] In summer 2014, Allardyce signed midfielder [[Cheikhou Kouyaté]], left-back [[Aaron Cresswell]], attacker [[Enner Valencia]], right-back (on loan from Arsenal) [[Carl Jenkinson]], striker [[Diafra Sakho]], defensive midfielder [[Alex Song]] (on loan from [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]]), midfielder [[Morgan Amalfitano]], and forward [[Mauro Zárate]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=302}}</ref> In October 2014, pundits like BBC's [[Robbie Savage]] were commenting about the team's "more attractive and attacking playing style"<ref name=sava>[https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29730838 "Robbie Savage on West Ham, Sunderland and Louis van Gaal"], BBC Sport, 24 October 2014</ref> or "the statistics [that] show the progress that West Ham have made in the last few months."<ref name=sava/><ref>[http://foreverwestham.com/2014/10/blog-topics/five-reasons-why-big-sam-deserves-a-new-contract-at-west-ham "Five reasons why Big Sam deserves a new contract at West Ham"], ''Forever West Ham'', 23 October 2014</ref> Allardyce was awarded the Premier League Manager of the Month for October 2014 after three wins for West Ham out of four games played that month.<ref name=Oct2014>{{cite web|url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/news/2014-15/nov/sam-allardyce-diafra-sakho-win-barclays-monthly-awards.html |title=West Ham exceed Allardyce's expectations |publisher=Premier League |date=7 November 2014 |accessdate=13 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> Allardyce left West Ham on 24 May 2015, the final day of the season, after his contract was not renewed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Premier League – Final Day: West Ham Statement|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/live/football/32536401|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=24 May 2015}}</ref> Allardyce stated that "I didn't want to stay. ===Sunderland=== [[File:Sunderland 3 Chelsea2 (26896979805).jpg|thumb|left|upright|Allardyce (left) in charge of Sunderland in May 2016]] On 9 October 2015, Allardyce was named the new [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] manager, replacing [[Dick Advocaat]].<ref name="sunapp">{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34491345 | title=Sunderland appoint Sam Allardyce as new manager on two-year deal | publisher=BBC Sport | date=9 October 2015 | accessdate=9 October 2015}}</ref> When Allardyce was appointed, Sunderland sat 19th in the Premier League table with three points from their first eight games of the season.<ref name="sunapp"/> Signing a two-year contract, he became the first manager to have managed both Newcastle United and Sunderland. On 25 October, in his second game as manager, he guided Sunderland to a 3–0 win against rivals and his former club Newcastle United.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sunderland 3–0 Newcastle|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34564966|accessdate=26 October 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 October 2015}}</ref> However, after a run of 5 defeats in a row in December, Sunderland headed into the second half of the season in the relegation zone with only 12 points from 19 games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccernews.com/sunderland-0-1-liverpool-fifth-defeat-in-a-row-leaves-black-cats-deep-in-the-relegation-zone/189407/|title=Sunderland 0–1 Liverpool: Fifth defeat in a row leaves Black Cats deep in the relegation zone|work=soccernews.com}}</ref>
In the January transfer window he signed centre-backs [[Lamine Koné]] and [[Jan Kirchhoff]] and attacking midfielder [[Wahbi Khazri]].<ref>{{Cite news |title=Lamine Kone signs for Sunderland |url=http://www.safc.com/news/team-news/2016/january/lamine-kone-signs-for-sunderland|publisher=Sunderland AFC |date=27 January 2016 |accessdate=27 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=Black Cats sign Wahbi Khazri |url=http://www.safc.com/news/team-news/2016/january/sunderland-sign-khazri |publisher=Sunderland A.F.C. |date=30 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=Black Cats Sign Kirchhoff |url=http://www.safc.com/news/team-news/2016/january/black-cats-sign-kirchhoff|publisher=Sunderland AFC |date=7 January 2016 |accessdate=7 January 2016}}</ref> On 6 February 2016, Sunderland scored two late goals to draw 2–2 with Liverpool at Anfield, having trailed 2–0 with ten minutes remaining.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35447637|title=Liverpool 2–2 Sunderland|date=6 February 2016|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Later that week winger [[Adam Johnson (footballer)|Adam Johnson]] was sacked by the club after pleading guilty to one count of sexual activity with a child and one charge of grooming.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35546894|title=Adam Johnson sacked by Sunderland after child sex charge admission|date=11 February 2016|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Sunderland remained in the relegation zone for much of the remainder of the [[2015–16 Sunderland A.F.C. season|2015–16]] season, before they boosted their survival chances by beating [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] 3–0 at [[Carrow Road]] on 16 April, closing the gap on 17th-place Norwich to just one point.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Henson|first1=Mike|title=Sunderland climbed to within a point of safety by beating relegation rivals Norwich at Carrow Road|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36003811|accessdate=29 April 2016|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Allardyce successfully led Sunderland to safety from relegation after beating [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] 3–0 on 11 May, a result which also ensured the relegation of rivals (and one of his former clubs) Newcastle United.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35733486 | title=Sunderland 3–0 Everton | publisher=BBC Sport | date=11 May 2016 | accessdate=12 May 2016}}</ref> Allardyce earned praise for his management of Sunderland from some [[pundit]]s, particularly for his organized approach and emphasis on a strong [[Defender (association football)|defence]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2016/05/12/rio-ferdinand-praises-sam-allardyce-after-sunderland-avoid-the-d/ | title=Rio Ferdinand praises Sam Allardyce after Sunderland avoid the drop | work=hitc.com | accessdate=14 May 2016}}</ref>
===England=== [[File:SamAllardyceCPFC.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Allardyce (front) as Crystal Palace manager]] On 22 July 2016, Allardyce signed a two-year contract to become manager of the [[England national football team|England national team]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Sam Allardyce named England manager by the Football Association|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36860245|accessdate=22 July 2016|work=BBC Sport|date=22 July 2016}}</ref> He won his first and only game in charge on 4 September, as an [[Adam Lallana]] goal deep into injury-time was enough to beat [[Slovakia national football team|Slovakia]] on the opening day of [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|qualification]] for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=McNulty|first1=Phil|title=Slovakia 0–1 England|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37207681|accessdate=4 September 2016|work=BBC Sport|date=4 September 2016}}</ref> Following [[2016 English football scandal|allegations of malpractice]], Allardyce left the role by mutual consent on 27 September, having managed the team for just 67 days and one match.<ref name="SSN resignation" />
===Crystal Palace===
On 23 December 2016, Allardyce signed a two-and-a-half-year contract to become manager of [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], a day after the sacking of [[Alan Pardew]].<ref>{{cite news|first= David |last=Ornstein|title=Sam Allardyce appointed Crystal Palace manager as Alan Pardew's successor| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38419024 |accessdate=23 December 2016|work=BBC Sport|date=23 December 2016}}</ref> He strengthened in the January transfer window by spending around £30 million on [[Jeffrey Schlupp]], [[Patrick van Aanholt]], and [[Luka Milivojević]].<ref name="WindowSummary">{{Cite news |title=Premier League ins and outs |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/feb/01/transfer-window-premier-league-club-by-club |publisher=The Guardian |date=1 February 2017 |accessdate=3 February 2017}}</ref> The "Eagles" confirmed their safety from relegation in the penultimate game of the [[2016–17 Crystal Palace F.C. season|2016–17]] season with a 4–0 victory over [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] at [[Selhurst Park]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Malyon|first1=Ed|title=Allardyce put out the flames at Palace, now the rebuilding starts|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/sam-allardyce-crystal-palace-mamadou-sakho-fabian-delph-yohan-cabaye-a7737606.html|accessdate=16 May 2017|work=The Independent|date=15 May 2017}}</ref> Allardyce announced his departure from Crystal Palace on 23 May 2017, saying he had no intention of seeking another job, in what was interpreted as a retirement announcement.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sam Allardyce resigns as Crystal Palace manager after five months|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40021059|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=23 May 2017|date=23 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Phil|title=Odds slashed on sensational Sunderland return but Big Sam confirms he is to retire from football|url=http://www.sunderlandecho.com/sport/football/sunderland-afc/odds-slashed-on-sensational-sunderland-return-but-big-sam-confirms-he-is-to-retire-from-football-1-8559074|publisher=[[Sunderland Echo]]|accessdate=23 May 2017|date=23 May 2017}}</ref> However, on 19 July 2017, Allardyce said he would be open to an international management position, but not another club job.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/40653075|title=Sam Allardyce: Former England & Crystal Palace boss open to international job|date=19 July 2017|publisher=|accessdate=20 July 2017|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref>
===Everton=== Despite previously announcing his retirement from his managerial career, on 30 November 2017, Allardyce signed a contract to manage [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] until June 2019, who were thirteenth place in the [[Premier League]] table, following a poor start to the [[2017–18 Everton F.C. season|2017–18]] season.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42186164|title=Sam Allardyce: New Everton boss signs deal until the summer of 2019|date=30 November 2017|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=30 November 2017}}</ref> His first game in charge came two days later, when his side defeated [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] in a 2–0 victory.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/match/22486|title=Everton v Huddersfield, 2017/18|publisher=Premier League website|accessdate=15 December 2017|date=2 December 2017}}</ref> He guided the "Toffees" to a seven-game unbeaten run at the start of his tenure, a spell which included five clean sheets.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rimmer|first1=Joe|title=Everton fans argue over Allardyce style after WBA draw|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/everton-fans-split-sam-allardyce-14082963|accessdate=31 December 2017|work=Liverpool Echo|date=26 December 2017}}</ref> Having steadied the defence, he stated that his next task was to bring in a consistent goalscorer.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rimmer|first1=Joe|title=Allardyce says the best of his Everton won't show until next season|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/sam-allardyce-admits-wont-see-14096379|accessdate=31 December 2017|work=Liverpool Echo|date=30 December 2017}}</ref> Everton ended the season in eighth-position, but fans were dissatisfied with the style of play. Whilst under Allardyce's management, Everton were ranked 20th for total shots, 19th for total shots on target, 16th for passing accuracy and 17th for shots faced in the Premier League.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/SkySportsStatto/status/996683148028272640/photo/1|title=Sky Sports Statto on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=16 May 2018|language=en}}</ref> Allardyce left the club on 16 May 2018.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sam Allardyce: Everton manager leaves club after six months in charge|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44136661|accessdate=16 May 2018|work=BBC Sport|date=16 May 2018}}</ref>
==Managerial style== Allardyce is a keen proponent of [[sports science]] and using technology and innovative techniques in coaching his teams,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hardy|first1=Martin|title=The hidden side of Sam Allardyce|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/football-league/the-hidden-side-of-sam-allardyce-7583949.html|accessdate=15 March 2016|work=The Independent|date=24 March 2012}}</ref> such as computerised performance analysis and [[yoga]].<ref name="16 October">{{cite news|title=Sam Allardyce: the inside story of his life as a manager before Sunderland|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/oct/16/sam-allardyce-sunderland-manager|accessdate=15 March 2016|work=The Guardian|date=16 October 2015}}</ref> Martin Hardy of ''[[The Independent]]'' described him as "one of the pioneers of sports science in English football".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hardy|first1=Martin|title=Arsenal vs Sunderland: How Sam Allardyce has revived Black Cats|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/how-sam-allardyce-has-revived-sunderland-a6760956.html|accessdate=15 March 2016|work=The Independent|date=5 December 2015}}</ref> Former players and pundits have cited his preparation as his main strength, which allows his teams to have better organisation and defensive stability.<ref name="16 October"/> Former Bolton player [[Kevin Davies]] also highlighted Allardyce's man-management skills as a strength.<ref name="16 October"/>
Allardyce also has a reputation for using [[long ball]] tactics, though he has said that this perception is "totally and utterly wrong".<ref>{{cite news|title=Sam Allardyce claims his reputation for being a long-ball merchant is 'utterly wrong'|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11685/8653564/sam-allardyce-claims-his-reputation-for-being-a-long-ball-merchant-is-utterly-wrong|accessdate=15 March 2016|work=Sky Sports|date=20 April 2013}}</ref> Former Newcastle player [[Lee Clark (footballer)|Lee Clark]] defended Allardyce from criticism of his tactics and said that Allardyce was right to work hard on set-plays and on the organisation of his team.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ryder|first1=Lee|title=Sam Allardyce is no long ball merchant, says former Newcastle United favourite Lee Clark|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/sam-allardyce-no-long-ball-10322821|accessdate=15 March 2016|work=Chronicle Live|date=24 October 2015}}</ref>
Criticism of his perceived long-ball tactics became more intense as he managed West Ham United in the Premier League, including discontent from West Ham's own supporters.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2014/01/01/fulham-west-ham_n_4527738.html | title=Fulham 2–1 West Ham: Sam Allardyce Running Out Of Time | work=The Huffington Post | accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/news/gold-defends-allardyce-tactics | title=Gold defends Allardyce tactics | publisher=fourfourtwo.com | accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ftbpro.com/posts/connor.whelan/639087/is-sam-allardyce-the-man-to-take-west-ham-forward | title=Is Sam Allardyce the Man to Take West Ham Forward? | work=ftbpro.com | date=24 January 2014 | accessdate=30 January 2014 | author=Whelan, Connor | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201223350/http://www.ftbpro.com/posts/connor.whelan/639087/is-sam-allardyce-the-man-to-take-west-ham-forward | archivedate=1 February 2014 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> In January 2014, following a 0–0 draw at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] manager, [[José Mourinho]] criticised West Ham's football, likening it to "football from the 19th century".<ref name="19th century">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25956108 | title=West Ham play 19th-century football – Jose Mourinho | publisher=BBC Sport | date=29 January 2014 | accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref> In October 2014, Allardyce claimed his reputation for playing long ball football was "not founded in fact" and had been used as an excuse by opposing managers such as [[Arsène Wenger]], [[David O'Leary]], [[Graeme Souness]] and [[Rafael Benítez]] following defeats by sides managed by Allardyce.<ref name=telegraph1014/> Allardyce wrote in his autobiography that "when they hit a 50-yard ball it was a cultural pass; when we did it, it was a hopeful hoof".<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=177}}</ref>
==Personal life== He met his wife Lynne Ward while still a youth team player at Bolton Wanderers, and the pair married on 1 June 1974.<ref name="page 46">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=46}}</ref> They had a son, [[Craig Allardyce|Craig]] (9 June 1975), and daughter, Rachael (21 April 1979).<ref name="page 44">{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=44}}</ref><ref name="page 46"/> He was given an honorary doctorate by the [[University of Bolton]] in July 2010.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/manchester/hi/people_and_places/newsid_8826000/8826259.stm | title = University of Bolton gives Sam Allardyce doctorate |publisher=BBC | date = 15 July 2010 | accessdate =13 December 2010 }}</ref> In addition to his football career, Allardyce has also run a number of businesses, including a motor spares firm, a fast-food restaurant, a social club, a [[public house|pub]], a piano bar, and a pub restaurant.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=82}}</ref> He published his autobiography, ''Big Sam'', in October 2015.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rafael Benitez 'had nothing to do with Liverpool winning Champions League'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/liverpool/11928257/Rafael-Benitez-had-nothing-to-do-with-Liverpool-winning-Champions-League.html|accessdate=4 April 2016|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=13 October 2015}}</ref>
In January 2013, Allardyce received "substantial", but undisclosed, damages from former Blackburn Rovers manager [[Steve Kean]]. In 2011, Kean had been recorded in a bar in Hong Kong alleging that Allardyce had been sacked from his post at Blackburn Rovers because he was a "crook".<ref name=SteveKeandamages>{{cite web |title=Steve Kean pays Sam Allardyce damages over 'crook' claim |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21044001 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 January 2013 |accessdate=16 January 2013}}</ref>
==Corruption allegations==
===2006 ''Panorama'' investigation===
{{Main|2006 English football corruption investigation}}
On 19 September 2006, Allardyce, and his son, [[Craig Allardyce|Craig]], were implicated in a [[BBC]] ''[[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]]'' documentary, ''Undercover: Football's Dirty Secrets'', which alleged that he had taken bribes from agents for signing certain players. Two agents, Teni Yerima and [[Peter Harrison (footballer)|Peter Harrison]], were secretly filmed, each separately claiming that they had paid Allardyce through his son. Allardyce denied ever taking, or asking for, a bribe.<ref>{{cite news | title = Agents claim manager was bribed |publisher=BBC | date = 19 September 2006 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/5360700.stm | accessdate =17 December 2006}}</ref> Others implicated of wrongdoing were [[Harry Redknapp]], [[Kevin Bond (English footballer)|Kevin Bond]], and [[Frank Arnesen]].<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=206}}</ref> As a result of the allegation, Allardyce refused to speak to the BBC.<ref name="Stevens 'bung' probe identifies 50 suspect Premiership transfers">{{cite news | title = Stevens 'bung' probe identifies 50 suspect Premiership transfers | url = https://www.theguardian.com/football/2006/sep/24/newsstory.sport1 |work=The Guardian | date = 24 September 2006 | accessdate =17 December 2008 | location=London | first=Denis | last=Campbell}}</ref> While he also stated he was going to sue the broadcaster to clear his name,<ref name="Allardyce planning to sue the BBC">{{cite news | title = Allardyce planning to sue the BBC | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/5378842.stm |publisher=BBC | date = 25 September 2006 | accessdate =17 December 2008}}</ref> Allardyce failed to issue libel proceedings as he was advised that suing for damage to reputation was a costly and time-consuming process.<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=207}}</ref> The final report of the [[2006 allegations of corruption in English football#Stevens report|Stevens inquiry]] published in June 2007 expressed concerns regarding the involvement of Craig Allardyce in a number of transactions, stating that: "The inquiry remains concerned at the conflict of interest that it believes existed between Craig Allardyce, his father Sam Allardyce—the then manager at Bolton—and the club itself."<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2315305/Stevens-puts-spotlight-on-the-agents.html | title = Stevens puts spotlight on the agents |work=The Daily Telegraph | date = 16 June 2007 | accessdate =17 December 2008 | location=London | first=David | last=Bond}}</ref> Allardyce stated that the inquiry was a [[public relations]] exercise and that the conclusion of a "conflict of interest" was "innuendo, without any facts".<ref>{{harvnb|Allardyce|2015|p=211}}</ref>
===2014 Ravel Morrison situation===
In February 2014, [[Daniel Taylor (journalist)|Daniel Taylor]], chief football writer for ''[[The Guardian]]'' and ''[[The Observer]]'', wrote that West Ham player and [[England national football team|England]] prospect [[Ravel Morrison]] felt he had come "under considerable pressure" from Allardyce to sign up with football agent Mark Curtis, who represents Allardyce himself and a number of other West Ham players, including [[Kevin Nolan]], [[James Tomkins (footballer)|James Tomkins]], [[Jack Collison]], [[Matt Jarvis]], [[Andy Carroll]], and [[Jussi Jääskeläinen]].<ref name=taylor>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/feb/15/ravel-morrison-west-ham-united-waste|title=Ravel Morrison's unravelling at West Ham United is a tremendous waste|author=Daniel Taylor|work=The Guardian|accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref> Agent Curtis had been charged and eventually cleared by the Football Association during the [[2006 English football corruption investigation#2008 investigations|2008 investigation into Luton Town's illegal transfer dealings]].<ref name=taylor/> Curtis responded to the allegations by saying it is "nonsense", while Allardyce talked of Morrison complaining about "a [[groin]] injury" while the club's medical staff could find "no problem",<ref name=taylor/> and made a reference to the player's "disciplinary issues in the past".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/24523344|title=Ravel Morrison: How West Ham player has turned his life around|author=Alistair Magowan|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref> Morrison was eventually loaned out to [[Football League Championship|Championship]] side [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] for the remainder of the 2013–14 season.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/feb/13/ravel-morrison-join-qpr-loan-west-ham|title=Ravel Morrison to join QPR on loan to boost promotion hopes|author=David Hytner|work=The Guardian|accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref>
===2016 ''Daily Telegraph'' investigation===
{{Main|2016 English football scandal}}
In September 2016, ''[[The Daily Telegraph|Daily Telegraph]]'' reporters posing as businessmen filmed Allardyce, who had recently been appointed the [[England national football team manager|manager]] of the [[England national football team|England football team]], allegedly offering to give advice on how to get around on [[The Football Association|FA]] rules on player [[Third-party ownership in association football|third party ownership]] and negotiating a £400,000 deal, subject to FA approval.<ref name="Telegraph 270916"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Sam Allardyce: England manager allegations investigated by FA| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37479135|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=27 September 2016|date=27 September 2016}}</ref> As a result, he left his job as England manager by mutual agreement with the FA after just one game in charge.<ref>{{Cite news| url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37483344| title=Sam Allardyce: England manager leaves after one match in charge|date=27 September 2016|work=BBC Sport |accessdate=27 September 2016}}</ref>
Robert Sullivan, Director of Strategy at the FA, later confirmed to the Commons Culture, Media and Sport Select Committee that Allardyce's comments were "a factual, correct statement around the laws of the English game and having third-party ownership"<ref>{{Cite news| url=http://data.parliament.uk/writtenevidence/committeeevidence.svc/evidencedocument/culture-media-and-sport-committee/the-governance-of-football/oral/41531.html:|title=The Governance of football |date=17 October 2016|work=Parliament.uk |accessdate=17 October 2016}}{{dead link| date=December 2016}}</ref>
Following a review by City of London Police, Allardyce was cleared of any wrongdoing with the Daily Telegraph also clarifying that it "did not suggest that Allardyce had broken the law"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/11/11/criminal-probe-into-suspected-bribery-launched-following-telegra/|title=Criminal probe launched following Telegraph's 'Football for Sale' investigation|date=11 November 2016|work=Daily Telegraph |accessdate=23 December 2016}}</ref>
Speaking to the Observer, Martin Glen, CEO of the FA, said that "it is a tragedy that we have ended up having to part company with him [Allardyce] over the, the – you know – entrapment".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/oct/22/martin-glenn-fa-england-sam-allardyce|title=FA's Martin Glenn: 'Why does the England shirt weigh so heavy?|last=Gibson|first=Owen|date=22 October 2016|work=The Guardian |accessdate=23 December 2016}}</ref>
